EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unstable conditions were in place along the edge of strong ridging across the region. Steep lapse rates and moderate shear allowed thunderstorms to develop on lake breeze boundaries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines reported down in and around Coloma.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unstable conditions were in place along the edge of strong ridging across the region. Steep lapse rates and moderate shear allowed thunderstorms to develop on lake breeze boundaries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weakening complex of thunderstorms moved into portions of northern Indiana and southern Lower Michigan. The thunderstorms were not able to mix down the stronger winds aloft as they moved through. However, a wake low behind the complex, in the somewhat cooler air, was able to mix down winds generally in the 30 to 40 mph range. While isolated reports of tree limbs down were received, damage across portions of Branch county was a bit more widespread.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported trees and power lines down in roughly 15 locations across the county. Damage is estimated at around $25,000.

An extended period of lake effect snow impacted Northwest Lower Michigan, from the 6th through the 9th.  Colder air entered the region on the 6th, behind a departing low pressure system.  A large upper low over Quebec gradually cycled back over the Great Lakes, helping to maintain lake effect snow for a lengthy period.  Wind directions changed substantially - from west-northwest to north-northeast and back to northwest - distributing the snow over a relatively large area.  Some of the higher snowfall totals included: 14 inches in Mancelona and 20 inches in Darragh by morning of the 7th; 19 inches in East Jordan and 24 inches in Bellaire by evening of the 7th; and 12 inches in Charlevoix on the day and night of the 7th-8th.

Bands of training thunderstorms affected parts of Northwest and North Central Lower Michigan.  Locally very heavy rain occurred in a few spots, including between Manistee and Cadillac.  The only flooding occurred in the Cross Village area of Emmet County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A culvert was washed out along Levering Road (C-66) a few miles east of Cross Village.  Substantial soil erosion occurred in the yards of some homes.  The co-operative observer, one mile east of Cross Village, measured 4.79 inches of rain in 12 hours, most of which fell in a four hour period either side of midnight.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms which weakened across Lake Michigan produced an outflow boundary. This boundary worked into far southern Lower Michigan and interacted with a lake breeze boundary to promote rapid storm development. Reports of damaging winds and some hail were received, but the storms failed to maintain their severity eastward as a large outflow boundary work across and south of the area, cutting off the limited available moisture.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported hail covering the ground ranging in size from peas to quarters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracking eastward through the Lower Great Lakes brought significant heavy wet snow to south central Upper Michigan.  With a strong high pressure system centered over Ontario providing very dry air across Lake Superior and northern Upper Michigan, there was a very sharp snowfall gradient between the heavy snow and no snow at all.  The pressure difference across the area also resulted in gusty east winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate snow fell mainly along and south of US 2.  The COOP observer near Norway reported 4 inches of heavy wet snow in less than 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front worked north into portions of far southern lower Michigan during the late morning hours. A line of severe thunderstorms developed in eastern Iowa and moved rapidly east into Indiana. Initially the storms were sub severe as they moved across Lake Michigan but quickly organized and became severe as they entered St. Joseph county. An area of wind damage occurred across St. Joseph county with a brief tornado touched down in Coldwater in Branch county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A survey of damage indicated the start of a roughly one mile wide swath of wind damage across northeastern Cass county. Numerous trees were damaged as a result of a concentrated burst of wind that continued into St. Joseph county in Michigan. Winds were likely in the 70 to 75 mph range as the line of storms moved into St. Joseph county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 19 year old swimmer walked to the end of the pier and jumped into the water where increasingly higher waves were observed. A combination of the strong current along the pier, increasing waves and 60 degree water all combined to cause problems for the novice swimmer. Officials located the body of the teen at 6:19 pm EDT 15 to 18 feet underwater.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local media reported that St. Joseph dive team and Coast Guard officials were called to Silver Beach around 5 pm EDT. A 19 year old swimmer walked to the end of the pier and jumped into the water where increasingly higher waves were observed. A combination of the strong current along the pier, increasing waves and 60 degree water all combined to cause problems for the novice swimmer. Officials located the body of the teen at 6:19 pm EDT 15 to 18 feet underwater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms which weakened across Lake Michigan produced an outflow boundary. This boundary worked into far southern Lower Michigan and interacted with a lake breeze boundary to promote rapid storm development. Reports of damaging winds and some hail were received, but the storms failed to maintain their severity eastward as a large outflow boundary work across and south of the area, cutting off the limited available moisture.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement officials reported several trees and power lines down in the Coloma area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms which weakened across Lake Michigan produced an outflow boundary. This boundary worked into far southern Lower Michigan and interacted with a lake breeze boundary to promote rapid storm development. Reports of damaging winds and some hail were received, but the storms failed to maintain their severity eastward as a large outflow boundary work across and south of the area, cutting off the limited available moisture.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement officials reported several tree limbs down as well as power line across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A waterspout was observed for 15 to 20 seconds over the Dead River Basin on the afternoon of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A waterspout was observed for 15 to 20 seconds near the north shore of the Dead River Basin.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced large hail near Germfask on the afternoon of the 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickle to quarter-sized hail was observed at the far west end of Big Manistique Lake just east of Germfask.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong frontal boundary swept across Lake Michigan into southwestern Lower Michigan. A narrow line of showers and storms formed on the front and was briefly able to bring stronger wind gusts to the surface as it came onshore. The line continued east, but wind speed were sub severe.

An upper level system sparked thunderstorms across Illinois during the early morning hours of the 7th. These moved into northern Indiana during the late morning and continued through the afternoon. Reports of 60 to 70 mph wind gusts and some hail were received.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported hail ranging from pea to nickel size falling for around 5 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level system sparked thunderstorms across Illinois during the early morning hours of the 7th. These moved into northern Indiana during the late morning and continued through the afternoon. Reports of 60 to 70 mph wind gusts and some hail were received.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported power lines and trees down throughout Lincoln Township. A portion of the roof of an abandoned house near Notre Dame was ripped off.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level system sparked thunderstorms across Illinois during the early morning hours of the 7th. These moved into northern Indiana during the late morning and continued through the afternoon. Reports of 60 to 70 mph wind gusts and some hail were received.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported a 18 inch diameter healthy tree blown down by the strong winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous strong to severe thunderstorms developed, producing large hail and damaging winds in spots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fifteen to twenty-five large trees were snapped off or uprooted.  A swing set was destroyed by a falling tree.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous strong to severe thunderstorms developed, producing large hail and damaging winds in spots.

A deep low pressure system moving through northwest Ontario pushed a warm front across western Upper Michigan in the morning hours...followed by a cold frontal passage in the afternoon.  The frontal boundaries produced several severe thunderstorms and two weak tornadoes over western Upper Michigan on the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter at the headquarters of Porcupine Mountains State Park reported severe downdrafts, trees falling, dime-sized hail, significant lightning and heavy rain and runoff for approximately 20 minutes.  Four large trees fell across roads, blocking lanes in the park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep low pressure system moving through northwest Ontario pushed a warm front across western Upper Michigan in the morning hours...followed by a cold frontal passage in the afternoon.  The frontal boundaries produced several severe thunderstorms and two weak tornadoes over western Upper Michigan on the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong EF0 tornado with winds estimated around 85 mph touched down at the River Pines RV Park and Campground and then skipped northeastward across the village lifting on the east side of the Ontonagon Golf Course.  Most of the damage was confined to snapped and uprooted trees, snapped power poles, a small flipped boat, minor roof damage, and some structural damage to a garage.  There were no injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated strong thunderstorm produced nickel-sized hail.
Strong to severe thunderstorms developed along and just ahead of an incoming cold front.
Strong to severe thunderstorms developed along and just ahead of an incoming cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two trees and several large limbs were downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms developed along and just ahead of an incoming cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four large, live maples were downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms developed along and just ahead of an incoming cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree limbs downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms developed along and just ahead of an incoming cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds well behind a line of thunderstorms downed several trees and power lines in Indian River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms developed along and just ahead of an incoming cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many trees and power lines were downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms developed along and just ahead of an incoming cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large tree limbs were downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms developed along and just ahead of an incoming cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sporadic tree damage, including a few roads blocked by fallen trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level system sparked thunderstorms across Illinois during the early morning hours of the 7th. These moved into northern Indiana during the late morning and continued through the afternoon. Reports of 60 to 70 mph wind gusts and some hail were received.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported multiple trees and tree limbs down at the intersection of Gumwood and Redfield Drives.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across the region during the evening hours of the 2nd into the overnight hours of the 3rd. Extreme instability existed across western Illinois and eastern Iowa. A line of storms developed and moved into far southern Lower Michigan  producing gusty winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reports of trees and tree limbs down were received from the public in the Millburg area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms developed along and just ahead of an incoming cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were downed.  One tree in Onekama was left leaning on a home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hail up to seven eighths of an inch in diameter was reported with an early morning thunderstorm which affected Spring Arbor in Jackson county.  The thunderstorm developed well to the northeast of a warm front in an area of enhanced elevated instability.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Media reported seven eighths inch diameter hail accompanied an early morning thunderstorm in Spring Arbor.  The media also reported moth ball (three quarters inch) hail four miles south southwest of Jackson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon hours of the 12th across portions of Allegan and Barry counties, resulting in hail reports of up to one inch in diameter.  The thunderstorms were very slow movers and also produced reports of significant rainfall with minor flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported three quarters inch diameter hail two miles north of Hopkins.  The storm tracked very slowly east northeast and went on to produce trained spotter and public reports of one inch hail four miles west southwest of Wayland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across the region during the evening hours of the 2nd into the overnight hours of the 3rd. Extreme instability existed across western Illinois and eastern Iowa. A line of storms developed and moved into far southern Lower Michigan  producing gusty winds.
Strong to severe thunderstorms developed along and just ahead of an incoming cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees and power lines were downed by winds associated with a wake low, in and just west of Cadillac.  A pick-up truck was heavily damaged by a falling tree.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms developed along and just ahead of an incoming cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees downed.

Reports of damaging winds and some hail were received, but the storms failed to maintain their severity eastward as a large outflow boundary work across and south of the area, cutting off the limited available moisture.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported multiple eight inch diameter tree limbs down at Nottawa Road and M-86.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported tree limbs down onto power lines near Union City. A transformer was on fire on one of the power poles that was affected.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mostly pea sized hail, though a few stones as large as nickels.

The frontal boundaries produced several severe thunderstorms and two weak tornadoes over western Upper Michigan on the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An apple tree six inches in diameter was knocked down.  Various tree branches three inches in diameter were also down.  Hanging plants were blown off the porch.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated at 30 mph from the storm.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pea to penny-sized hail was also reported 3.5 miles south of Republic.

Reports of damaging winds and some hail were received, but the storms failed to maintain their severity eastward as a large outflow boundary work across and south of the area, cutting off the limited available moisture.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter recorded a 71 mph wind gust just to the northwest of Three Rivers.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms which weakened across Lake Michigan produced an outflow boundary. This boundary worked into far southern Lower Michigan and interacted with a lake breeze boundary to promote rapid storm development. A moisture-laden low pressure system moving from the mid-Mississippi Valley into the Great Lakes region dropped heavy snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 9th into the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A resident three miles east of Kenton measured 7.5 inches of storm total snowfall in less than 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moisture-laden low pressure system moving from the mid-Mississippi Valley into the Great Lakes region dropped heavy snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 9th into the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter near Iron River measured nine inches of snow in less than 12 hours.  The wet heavy snow and north winds gusting to 30 mph caused numerous minor accidents, power outages and some tree damage.  West Iron County schools were closed on the 10th while Forest Park School had a two-hour delay.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the late night hours producing wind gusts of over 60 mph across portions of Van Buren, Kalamazoo, Calhoun and Jackson counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Kalamazoo county road commission reported widely scattered tree damage across portions of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An outflow boundary extended from southeastern Lower Michigan to northern Illinois. Mixed layer CAPE in excess of 2500 j/kg and moderate shear allowed for stronger thunderstorms to develop. As they became organized and established cold pools, the storms transitioned from hail producers to mainly producing wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amateur radio operators reported a tree down near the intersection of Hadley and Herring Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An outflow boundary extended from southeastern Lower Michigan to northern Illinois. Mixed layer CAPE in excess of 2500 j/kg and moderate shear allowed for stronger thunderstorms to develop. As they became organized and established cold pools, the storms transitioned from hail producers to mainly producing wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amateur radio operators reported a tree down at Squires and Genesee Road. A portion of a sheet metal roof was taken off a barn at Squires and Jonesville Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An outflow boundary extended from southeastern Lower Michigan to northern Illinois. Mixed layer CAPE in excess of 2500 j/kg and moderate shear allowed for stronger thunderstorms to develop. As they became organized and established cold pools, the storms transitioned from hail producers to mainly producing wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported a tree down onto a camper with two occupants. No injuries were reported. In addition, minor damage to cars and traliers in the area were reported from falling tree limbs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An outflow boundary extended from southeastern Lower Michigan to northern Illinois. As they became organized and established cold pools, the storms transitioned from hail producers to mainly producing wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement officials reported trees and power lines down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions gave way to a batch of thunderstorms, with numerous severe reports across southeast Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three trees were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions gave way to a batch of thunderstorms, with numerous severe reports across southeast Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening low pressure system moving through the Upper Great Lakes caused heavy rain, damaging north winds and power outages from the evening of the 29th into the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The West Iron County Fire Department reported power lines down from the storm while the Crystal Falls fire department observed a power outage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening low pressure system moving through the Upper Great Lakes caused heavy rain, damaging north winds and power outages from the evening of the 29th into the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several 5 to 6-inch diameter poplar trees were knocked down in Iron Mountain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening low pressure system moving through the Upper Great Lakes caused heavy rain, damaging north winds and power outages from the evening of the 29th into the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large trees fell across power lines just north of Menominee along Highway M-35.  Two to three-inch diameter tree limbs were also reported down over the south side of Menominee.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving through the Upper Great Lakes dumped a swath of heavy snow over much of west and north central Upper Michigan mainly in the afternoon and evening of the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven to eight inches of wet heavy snow fell from Sidnaw to Watton and Covington in less than a six-hour period with two-inch per hour snowfall rates reported at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving through the Upper Great Lakes dumped a swath of heavy snow over much of west and north central Upper Michigan mainly in the afternoon and evening of the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven to nine inches of wet heavy snow fell in the Sidnaw area in less than an eight-hour period.  Snowfall rates of two inches per hour were reported at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the late night hours producing wind gusts of over 60 mph across portions of Van Buren, Kalamazoo, Calhoun and Jackson counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media reported that aluminum siding was torn off of a house by estimated 50 to 60 mph wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late evening thunderstorm in Hart produced seven eighths inch diameter hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven eighths inch diameter hail was reported in Hart.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An outflow boundary extended from southeastern Lower Michigan to northern Illinois. Mixed layer CAPE in excess of 2500 j/kg and moderate shear allowed for stronger thunderstorms to develop. As they became organized and established cold pools, the storms transitioned from hail producers to mainly producing wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement officials reported trees and power lines down.

Mixed layer CAPE in excess of 2500 j/kg and moderate shear allowed for stronger thunderstorms to develop. As they became organized and established cold pools, the storms transitioned from hail producers to mainly producing wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials estimated a 60 mph wind gust in Coldwater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Intense thunderstorm rain lead to rainfall totals of 3 to 7 inches, generally in a 12 hour period of less, which lead to flash flooding across a few counties in southeast Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A nine inch diameter tree limb was down at the intersection of Oakley Park and Welch Roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Intense thunderstorm rain lead to rainfall totals of 3 to 7 inches, generally in a 12 hour period of less, which lead to flash flooding across a few counties in southeast Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flooding reported in the Ann Arbor and Ypsilanti areas, with cars stranded on Jackson road and I-94.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Intense thunderstorm rain lead to rainfall totals of 3 to 7 inches, generally in a 12 hour period of less, which lead to flash flooding across a few counties in southeast Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lots of roads flooded, including two feet of water reported near Hill and Fenton Roads. Cars reported stalled throughout the Flint area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Intense thunderstorm rain lead to rainfall totals of 3 to 7 inches, generally in a 12 hour period of less, which lead to flash flooding across a few counties in southeast Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Standing water on Interstate 75 throughout Detroit, cars stranded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Mason county emergency manager reported that a shower produced hail up to three quarters of an inch in diameter five miles northwest of Freesoil.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An emergency manager estimated hail size of three quarters of an inch accompanying a shower five miles northwest of Freesoil.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening low pressure system moving through the Upper Great Lakes caused heavy rain, damaging north winds and power outages from the evening of the 29th into the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were reported down in the Escanaba and Gladstone area as tree branches fell across roads and power lines.  Over 100 customers in rural Escanaba and Gladstone were without power into the evening of the 30th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening low pressure system moving through the Upper Great Lakes caused heavy rain, damaging north winds and power outages from the evening of the 29th into the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were reported down in the Manistique area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front pushed through southeast Michigan, with post frontal westerly wind gusts up around 45 mph. Tree limbs and power lines were brought down, which lead to 85,000 customers to be without electricity.

Two separate bow echoes moved across western lower Michigan during the morning hours of July 11, producing numerous reports of wind damage.  The first bow echo moved onshore north of Muskegon shortly after daybreak.  The second bow echo proved to be more destructive as it raced east from northern Illinois across far southern Lake Michigan and southern lower Michigan, resulting in numerous reports of downed trees and power lines.  One person lost his life in Cutlerville when a tree fell in the garage he was in.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media in Grand Rapids reported a measured wind gust of 66 mph at the White River lighthouse five miles southwest of Whitehall as the first bow echo came onshore. A trained spotter reported that many trees were blown down in Twin Lake by wind gusts estimated at 65 mph. Numerous trees were blown down across portions of the county, particularly near to just east northeast of Muskegon.  Muskegon county emergency management reported numerous trees down at Apple avenue and US-31.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees and power lines were blown down in Hart.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed at midday in Northeast Lower Michigan.  One storm developed into a supercell, and became a prolific hail producer.
Scattered thunderstorms developed at midday in Northeast Lower Michigan.  One storm developed into a supercell, and became a prolific hail producer.
An isolated strong thunderstorm dropped nickel-sized hail in Gladwin County.

The approach of an upper disturbance from Minnesota heralded one of the most significant severe weather events of the season on the 30th.  Widespread damage was reported from Ontonagon and Baraga counties east through Marquette and Delta counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Branches estimated to be six inches in diameter were reported down.  Pea-sized hail was also observed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees reported down...dimensions unknown.  Time was estimated by radar.  Pea-sized hail was also reported.

A strong cold front pushed through southeast Michigan, with post frontal westerly wind gusts up around 45 mph. Tree limbs and power lines were brought down, which lead to 85,000 customers to be without electricity.

A moisture-laden low pressure system moving from the mid-Mississippi Valley into the Great Lakes region dropped heavy snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 9th into the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Herman measured 13.1 inches of snow in 18 hours.  The wet snow caused numerous minor accidents, sporadic power outages and some tree damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moisture-laden low pressure system moving from the mid-Mississippi Valley into the Great Lakes region dropped heavy snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 9th into the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Weather Service in Negaunee Township measured 12.2 inches of wet heavy snow in less than 24 hours while the Ishpeming area measured around 10 inches.  In addition to numerous minor accidents, the combination of wet snow and north wind gusts to 35 mph caused power outages and sporadic tree damage throughout Marquette County. The storm closed schools in Ishpeming, Negaunee and Marquette on the 10th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two separate bow echoes moved across western lower Michigan during the morning hours of July 11, producing numerous reports of wind damage.  The first bow echo moved onshore north of Muskegon shortly after daybreak.  The second bow echo proved to be more destructive as it raced east from northern Illinois across far southern Lake Michigan and southern lower Michigan, resulting in numerous reports of downed trees and power lines.  One person lost his life in Cutlerville when a tree fell in the garage he was in.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported that in addition to three quarters inch hail thunderstorm wind gusts blew down several trees in Twin Lake.  This occurred with an area of storms that developed during the mid morning hours just to the north of the secondary bow echo that passed by just to the south of Muskegon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two separate bow echoes moved across western lower Michigan during the morning hours of July 11, producing numerous reports of wind damage.  The first bow echo moved onshore north of Muskegon shortly after daybreak.  The second bow echo proved to be more destructive as it raced east from northern Illinois across far southern Lake Michigan and southern lower Michigan, resulting in numerous reports of downed trees and power lines.  One person lost his life in Cutlerville when a tree fell in the garage he was in.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Radar data corroborated with ground truth reports indicates that a significant bow echo came onshore in Holland at 10:25 a.m. A storm chaser estimated that it produced wind gusts of up to 80 mph.  Numerous reports of trees and power lines were received from in and near Holland and radar data indicates additional wind damage was likely east northeast to Zeeland and Jenison.  The storm blew through Jenison at 10:45 a.m.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The approach of an upper disturbance from Minnesota heralded one of the most significant severe weather events of the season on the 30th.  Widespread damage was reported from Ontonagon and Baraga counties east through Marquette and Delta counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees reported down across town...dimension of trees unknown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The approach of an upper disturbance from Minnesota heralded one of the most significant severe weather events of the season on the 30th.  Widespread damage was reported from Ontonagon and Baraga counties east through Marquette and Delta counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six-inch diameter tree limb reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving through a moist unstable air mass produced severe thunderstorms over western Upper Michigan on the evening of the 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter and dime-sized hail were reported with the storm.  Winds were estimated up to 65 mph as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front pushed through southeast Michigan, with post frontal westerly wind gusts up around 45 mph. Tree limbs and power lines were brought down, which lead to 85,000 customers to be without electricity.

A strong cold front pushed through southeast Michigan, with post frontal westerly wind gusts up around 45 mph. Tree limbs and power lines were brought down, which lead to 85,000 customers to be without electricity.

Two separate bow echoes moved across western lower Michigan during the morning hours of July 11, producing numerous reports of wind damage.  The first bow echo moved onshore north of Muskegon shortly after daybreak.  The second bow echo proved to be more destructive as it raced east from northern Illinois across far southern Lake Michigan and southern lower Michigan, resulting in numerous reports of downed trees and power lines.  One person lost his life in Cutlerville when a tree fell in the garage he was in.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A bow echo raced east across Calhoun county during the late morning hours, weakening as it did so, but still bringing down several trees and tree limbs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two men were injured by a lightning strike while picking blueberries east of South Haven.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple media sources reported a lightning strike injured two males who were picking blueberries at the time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind damage included downed trees and power lines across portions of Calhoun, Kent and Ottawa counties.  The southern half of Newaygo county experienced significant flooding where campers in Henning Park just east northeast of the town of Newaygo were evacuated.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported seven eighths inch diameter hail in downtown Battle Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The approach of an upper disturbance from Minnesota heralded one of the most significant severe weather events of the season on the 30th.  Widespread damage was reported from Ontonagon and Baraga counties east through Marquette and Delta counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gust measured by the Iron Mountain ASOS.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven-inch diameter tree reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The approach of an upper disturbance from Minnesota heralded one of the most significant severe weather events of the season on the 30th.  Widespread damage was reported from Ontonagon and Baraga counties east through Marquette and Delta counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines and trees reported down in Lake Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The approach of an upper disturbance from Minnesota heralded one of the most significant severe weather events of the season on the 30th.  Widespread damage was reported from Ontonagon and Baraga counties east through Marquette and Delta counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous 3 to 4 inch diameter tree branches down.  Time was estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The approach of an upper disturbance from Minnesota heralded one of the most significant severe weather events of the season on the 30th.  Widespread damage was reported from Ontonagon and Baraga counties east through Marquette and Delta counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Various trees reported down on power lines.  Time is estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving through a moist unstable air mass produced severe thunderstorms over western Upper Michigan on the evening of the 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large branches were also reported down due to strong thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving through a moist unstable air mass produced severe thunderstorms over western Upper Michigan on the evening of the 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts greater than 50 mph were measured for 20 minutes.  A 63 mph wind gust was measured at 1859 EST.  Quarter-sized hail was measured as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front worked north into portions of far southern lower Michigan during the late morning hours. A line of severe thunderstorms developed in eastern Iowa and moved rapidly east into Indiana. Initially the storms were sub severe as they moved across Lake Michigan but quickly organized and became severe as they entered St. Joseph county. An area of wind damage occurred across St. Joseph county with a brief tornado touched down in Coldwater in Branch county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A survey of extensive tree damage was performed in northwestern St. Joseph county. While the majority of the damage was a result of straight-line winds, damage patterns indicate that a circulation briefly formed and touched down. The circulation touched down just west of Moore Park and moved rapidly northeast, dissipating near the intersection of Marcellus and Hutchinson Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A minor severe weather outbreak occurred across southwest lower Michigan on the afternoon of August 9th, as a cold front moved through the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A National Weather Service Storm Survey Team confirmed an EF-0 tornado briefly touched down on Tuesday, August 9th, 2011 in Lafayette Township in Gratiot County. This tornado was on the ground for about 250 yards in Lafeyette Township causing significant damage to a 99 year old family farm. This same storm produced a weak EF-0 tornado that touched down briefly for about 200 yards in a corn field in Lakefield Township in Saginaw County.  Some very minor crop damage was found along the path between the two tornado touchdowns. Maximum wind gusts were estimated to be around 80mph in Lafayette Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind damage included downed trees and power lines across portions of Calhoun, Kent and Ottawa counties.  The southern half of Newaygo county experienced significant flooding where campers in Henning Park just east northeast of the town of Newaygo were evacuated.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree came down and also took power lines down in Zeeland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind damage included downed trees and power lines across portions of Calhoun, Kent and Ottawa counties.  The southern half of Newaygo county experienced significant flooding where campers in Henning Park just east northeast of the town of Newaygo were evacuated.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One inch hail was reported in Grandville and some wind damage was reported in Comstock Park in the Westgate Bowl area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind damage included downed trees and power lines across portions of Calhoun, Kent and Ottawa counties.  The southern half of Newaygo county experienced significant flooding where campers in Henning Park just east northeast of the town of Newaygo were evacuated.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Calhoun county officials reported a severe thunderstorm blew down several trees onto M-66.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The approach of an upper disturbance from Minnesota heralded one of the most significant severe weather events of the season on the 30th.  Widespread damage was reported from Ontonagon and Baraga counties east through Marquette and Delta counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Approximately one-foot diameter trees reported down...along with multiple reports of power lines down.  Various 6-8 inch diameter branches were also reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The approach of an upper disturbance from Minnesota heralded one of the most significant severe weather events of the season on the 30th.  Widespread damage was reported from Ontonagon and Baraga counties east through Marquette and Delta counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell onto a power line.  Time is estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The approach of an upper disturbance from Minnesota heralded one of the most significant severe weather events of the season on the 30th.  Widespread damage was reported from Ontonagon and Baraga counties east through Marquette and Delta counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Menominee County Sheriff's Office reported numerous trees and power lines down across the northern portion of Menominee County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moisture-laden low pressure system moving from the mid-Mississippi Valley into the Great Lakes region dropped heavy snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 9th into the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two inches of wet slushy snow contributed to a fatal car crash near Rapid River at shortly before 430 pm on the afternoon of the 9th as reported by the Michigan State Police post in Gladstone.  Two elderly women from Rapid River were pronounced dead at the scene when the car they were driving slid out of control and was struck by an SUV driven by a 53-year-old Wisconsin man. The man was transported by ambulance to OSF St. Francis Hospital in Escanaba and was listed in fair condition the next day. Both vehicles were heavily damaged.||Several other accidents were reported in the Escanaba-Gladstone area with numerous calls of vehicles sliding into the ditch.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms which weakened across Lake Michigan produced an outflow boundary. This boundary worked into far southern Lower Michigan and interacted with a lake breeze boundary to promote rapid storm development. Reports of damaging winds and some hail were received, but the storms failed to maintain their severity eastward as a large outflow boundary work across and south of the area, cutting off the limited available moisture.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A fire official reported that a 17 year old female was struck by lightning at a campground while taking a shower. No specific details were given as to the extent of injuries, which are assumed minor.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front was located across the region. Showers and thunderstorms developed along and north of it, with some of these becoming severe. Hail was reported in several locations.
A warm front was located across the region. Showers and thunderstorms developed along and north of it, with some of these becoming severe. Hail was reported in several locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement officials reported mainly pea size hail, with a few hailstones to the size of nickels.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front was located across the region. Showers and thunderstorms developed along and north of it, with some of these becoming severe. Hail was reported in several locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported around eight large pine trees, roughly 40 to 50 feet tall, uprooted.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind damage included downed trees and power lines across portions of Calhoun, Kent and Ottawa counties.  The southern half of Newaygo county experienced significant flooding where campers in Henning Park just east northeast of the town of Newaygo were evacuated.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three quarters inch hail was reported one mile west of Jackson by an amateur radio operator.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the early to mid evening hours across portions of Kalamazoo, Calhoun and Jackson counties resulting in scattered downed trees and power lines from estimated wind gusts to 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter in Schoolcraft reported one inch diameter hail and wind gusts to 60 mph in downtown Schoolcraft.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The approach of an upper disturbance from Minnesota heralded one of the most significant severe weather events of the season on the 30th.  Widespread damage was reported from Ontonagon and Baraga counties east through Marquette and Delta counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to six-inch diameter tree limbs were reported down in Menominee.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to four-inch diameter branches were reported down.  A tree also fell on power lines, and a metal lawn chair was blown across the yard.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees reported down across roads and over power lines.  County Road 38 was closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unstable air mass along with moderate shear ahead of a upper level system, allowed for rapid thunderstorm development. A few reports of wind damage and hail were received.
An unstable air mass along with moderate shear ahead of a upper level system, allowed for rapid thunderstorm development. A few reports of wind damage and hail were received.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported several trees down.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement from Calhoun county that a downed tree also brought down several power lines one mile southeast of Albion near B and 29 mile roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind damage included downed trees and power lines across portions of Calhoun, Kent and Ottawa counties.  The southern half of Newaygo county experienced significant flooding where campers in Henning Park just east northeast of the town of Newaygo were evacuated.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were washed out as reported by road commission. Flash flooding occurred on 2nd avenue in South Haven and forced the cancellation of the National Blueberry Festival.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The approach of an upper disturbance from Minnesota heralded one of the most significant severe weather events of the season on the 30th.  Widespread damage was reported from Ontonagon and Baraga counties east through Marquette and Delta counties.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving through a warm and unstable airmass triggered a line of severe thunderstorms which affected portions of the Keweenaw Peninsula on the evening of the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 call center reported trees and power lines downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved across the region. Ahead of the front, temperatures were in the lower 90s with surface dewpoints well into the 70s. 30 to 40 knots of shear were also in place for the storm to work with. A strong elevated mixed layer was in place, limiting the potential for more explosive storm development. Reports of hail and damaging winds were received, but were sporadic.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement officials reported a tree down west of Lagrange.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unstable air mass along with moderate shear ahead of a upper level system, allowed for rapid thunderstorm development. A few reports of wind damage and hail were received.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported trees down 1 mile southeast of Union City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unstable air mass along with moderate shear ahead of a upper level system, allowed for rapid thunderstorm development. A few reports of wind damage and hail were received.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported a barn was destroyed on Campbell Road, between Freemont and Brocklebank Roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unstable air mass along with moderate shear ahead of a upper level system, allowed for rapid thunderstorm development. A few reports of wind damage and hail were received.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported several trees down on US-12, just west of Coldwater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unstable air mass along with moderate shear ahead of a upper level system, allowed for rapid thunderstorm development. A few reports of wind damage and hail were received.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported trees down five miles southeast of Union City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The approach of an upper disturbance from Minnesota heralded one of the most significant severe weather events of the season on the 30th.  Widespread damage was reported from Ontonagon and Baraga counties east through Marquette and Delta counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 40-foot by 70-foot section of the Fontana Terminal Building at the Ford Airport in Iron Mountain was torn off by winds exceeding 60 mph.  Two flights were cancelled due to the damage and the passengers were bused to Escanaba to catch alternate flights.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving through a warm and unstable airmass triggered a line of severe thunderstorms which affected portions of the Keweenaw Peninsula on the evening of the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Home on Mine Street sustained damage.  Windows were partially broken and garage door was bowing inward.  Rollers were blown off the garage door. Garage was shifted one inch off of foundation.  Garage door and damaged windows were on the windward side of house facing the southwest.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving through a warm and unstable airmass triggered a line of severe thunderstorms which affected portions of the Keweenaw Peninsula on the evening of the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A damage path stretched from Mine Street through the intersection of US-41 and Church Street in North Calumet. The damage path was oriented from southwest to northeast and estimated to be one-quarter mile wide.  Metal building housing a travel trailer destroyed.  Several trees estimated to be between 18 to 24 inches in diameter were uprooted.  A drill shop roof near the elementary school sustained significant damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving through a warm and unstable airmass triggered a line of severe thunderstorms which affected portions of the Keweenaw Peninsula on the evening of the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small wooden shed rolled once over a fence at Calumet Elementary School.  The shed was about 8 feet high and 12 feet wide.  Some playground equipment at the school was also tipped over.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving through a warm and unstable airmass triggered a line of severe thunderstorms which affected portions of the Keweenaw Peninsula on the evening of the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple locations along Caledonia Street had tree damage.  One house had a tree branch 1.5 feet in diameter fall onto a deck.  Other locations had 6 to 12-inch diameter branches down.  All of the branches were broken off in a north to northeast direction.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of thunderstorms in East Central Lower Michigan produced a few pockets of wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines were downed in the Gladwin area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few severe storms impacted areas south of M-59.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving through a warm and unstable airmass triggered a line of severe thunderstorms which affected portions of the Keweenaw Peninsula on the evening of the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Keweenaw County Sheriff reported a 150-yard stretch of approximately 40 trees uprooted or snapped just west of Copper Harbor.  The trees ranged from 6 to 18 inches in diameter and fell in the same general direction.  Several of the trees fell across Highway M-26 closing the highway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving through the Upper Great Lakes dumped a swath of heavy snow over much of west and north central Upper Michigan mainly in the afternoon and evening of the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters in and near Ironwood measured anywhere from 11 to 14 inches of wet heavy snow over a ten-hour time period.  The spotter just northwest of Ironwood reported snowfall rates of two to three inches per hour at times.   The Wakefield area reported over one-inch per hour snowfall rates during the event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving through the Upper Great Lakes dumped a swath of heavy snow over much of west and north central Upper Michigan mainly in the afternoon and evening of the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters measured six to seven inches of snow from Republic to Ishpeming.  Most of the snow fell in less than an eight-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong frontal boundary swept across Lake Michigan into southwestern Lower Michigan. A narrow line of showers and storms formed on the front and was briefly able to bring stronger wind gusts to the surface as it came onshore. The line continued east, but wind speed were sub severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local dispatchers reported several large diameter trees snapped and power poles pushed over by the strong winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep low pressure moving across the northern Great Lakes caused a pressure gradient across much of the region. Strong winds aloft were mixed down and caused pockets of wind damage, power outages and even some school closures due to the power outages. One death was reported when a tree fell onto a golfer, killing him instantly.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous reports of large trees and tree limbs being uprooted, snapped or suffering partial damage were received across Berrien County, including Benton Harbor, St, Joseph, Bridgman, and Coloma. The largest tree was found in St. Joseph where a 120 foot oak tree was uprooted, falling onto a occupied home on the 800 block of Oakridge. Additional trees were down across the area. Power was out to over 20,000 people at one point, forcing the closure of most schools in the county. Around 8:30 am, a 53 year old Chicago man was moving between the 1st and 2nd holes on the Dunes Golf Course when a large tree fell onto him, killing him instantly.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Small tree branches blown down, along with damage to a roof shed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Winds in the wake of a cold frontal passage gusted to 58 mph at Freda on the evening of the 13th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening low pressure system moving through the Upper Great Lakes caused heavy rain, damaging north winds and power outages from the evening of the 29th into the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An awning was blown off of a business on Highway US-45 in Rockland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening low pressure system moving through the Upper Great Lakes caused heavy rain, damaging north winds and power outages from the evening of the 29th into the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large white pine was knocked down.  Time was estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening low pressure system moving through the Upper Great Lakes caused heavy rain, damaging north winds and power outages from the evening of the 29th into the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were knocked down and hundreds were without power across Houghton County into the morning of the 30th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An outflow boundary extended from southeastern Lower Michigan to northern Illinois. Mixed layer CAPE in excess of 2500 j/kg and moderate shear allowed for stronger thunderstorms to develop. As they became organized and established cold pools, the storms transitioned from hail producers to mainly producing wind damage.
