EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions gave way to a batch of thunderstorms, with numerous severe reports across southeast Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees blown down or snapped along a 2 mile stretch.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching warm front produced a few severe thunderstorms and heavy rain over portions of Houghton County on the morning of the 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Most of the hail observed was between dime and quarter-sized, but a few stones were the size of golf balls.  In addition...wind gusts were estimated around 40 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wake low resulting from a thunderstorm complex moving through Wisconsin caused wind damage over Gogebic County on the afternoon of the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong southeast winds from a wake low knocked down numerous trees near Little Girls Point in far western Gogebic County.  Winds at the AWOS in Ironwood gusted near 50 mph during the event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front over Wisconsin generated severe thunderstorms with large hail over portions of western Upper Michigan on the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were multiple reports of estimated quarter-sized hail between Bruce Crossing and Trout Creek.  Time of the reports was estimated from radar imagery.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front over Wisconsin generated severe thunderstorms with large hail over portions of western Upper Michigan on the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pea to penny-sized hail was reported.  Time of the report was estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front over Wisconsin generated severe thunderstorms with large hail over portions of western Upper Michigan on the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail tapered off to pea-sized by 237 am CST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front over Wisconsin generated severe thunderstorms with large hail over portions of western Upper Michigan on the 11th.
Cold air in the wake of an Alberta low clipper system resulted in moderate lake effect snow showers over northern Luce County on the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers near Two Heart and Deer Park measured four inches of lake effect snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of clipper low pressure systems moving through the region helped generate moderate to heavy lake effect snow showers downwind of Lake Superior in a northwest to north flow from the 6th into the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated six to eight inches of snow fell between the Marquette-Alger County line and Eben Junction in a 12-hour period.  Several accidents were observed on area roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of clipper low pressure systems moving through the region helped generate moderate to heavy lake effect snow showers downwind of Lake Superior in a northwest to north flow from the 6th into the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter four miles northeast of Calumet measured 11 inches of snow in the 12-hour period ending on the morning of the 8th and reported visibility reduced to one-quarter mile in heavy snow and blowing snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of clipper low pressure systems moving through the region helped generate moderate to heavy lake effect snow showers downwind of Lake Superior in a northwest to north flow from the 6th into the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter at Herman measured nearly 20 inches of snow in the 24-hour period ending on the morning of the 8th with a four-day storm total snowfall of 33 inches ending on the morning of the 9th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from the Plains toward eastern Upper Michigan dumped heavy wet snow over portions of western Upper Michigan on the 3rd and 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Ironwood measured 6.5 inches of wet heavy snow in 12 hours.  An estimated eight inches of snow fell near Lake Gogebic State Park in about a 12-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from the Plains toward eastern Upper Michigan dumped heavy wet snow over portions of western Upper Michigan on the 3rd and 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter near Sidnaw measured five inches of wet heavy snow in just over 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from the Plains toward eastern Upper Michigan dumped heavy wet snow over portions of western Upper Michigan on the 3rd and 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter near Iron River measured 5.5 inches of snow in just over 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of clipper low pressure systems moving through the region helped generate moderate to heavy lake effect snow showers downwind of Lake Superior in a northwest to north flow from the 6th into the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter near Carlshend measured 11 inches of snow in a 12-hour period ending on the morning of the 8th while a spotter near Ishpeming estimated nearly a foot of snow in 12 hours.  The combination of heavy snow and blowing snow reduced visibility to one-quarter mile or less in the afternoon of the 8th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of clipper low pressure systems moving through the region helped generate moderate to heavy lake effect snow showers downwind of Lake Superior in a northwest to north flow from the 6th into the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter near Ironwood measured ten inches of snow in 12 hours.  Blowing snow from gusty north winds to 25 mph combined with the heavy snow to reduce visibility less than one-quarter at times from the afternoon of the 7th into the morning of the 8th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of clipper low pressure systems moving through the region helped generate moderate to heavy lake effect snow showers downwind of Lake Superior in a northwest to north flow from the 6th into the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated three to four inches of snow was reported in Rock in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of clipper low pressure systems moving through the region helped generate moderate to heavy lake effect snow showers downwind of Lake Superior in a northwest to north flow from the 6th into the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated 7 to 9 inches of snow fell in 24 hours over portions of northern Schoolcraft County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Colder air in the wake of a frontal passage generated briefly heavy lake effect snow over eastern Marquette and Alger County from the afternoon of the 22nd continuing into the early morning of the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter in Harvey measured five inches of lake effect snow in three and a half hours late on the 22nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Colder air in the wake of a frontal passage generated briefly heavy lake effect snow over eastern Marquette and Alger County from the afternoon of the 22nd continuing into the early morning of the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter near Chatham measured 5.5 inches of lake effect snow in five hours late on the 22nd.  The observer south of Grand Marais also reported over five inches of snow in the 12-hour period ending on the morning of the 23rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure trough moving across the area dumped moderate snow near Copper Harbor on the 29th.  One to three inches of snow elsewhere caused very slippery roads and contributed to a fatal accident in Marquette County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated four to six inches of snow fell near Copper Harbor in a nine-hour period on the 29th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure trough moving across the area dumped moderate snow near Copper Harbor on the 29th.  One to three inches of snow elsewhere caused very slippery roads and contributed to a fatal accident in Marquette County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A quick inch of wet snow created slippery roads and contributed to a fatal accident just south of Marquette Mountain on Highway M-553 around 10 am on the 29th.  A 26 year-old Gwinn man was killed when the northbound car he was driving spun out of  control and crashed into a garbage truck heading southbound.  The six-month old daughter of the Gwinn man was injured in the crash and transported to Marquette General Hospital. She was listed in stable condition the next day. The driver of the garbage truck was not injured.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front over Wisconsin generated severe thunderstorms with large hail over portions of western Upper Michigan on the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck and damaged the steeple tower of the Keweenaw Heritage Center at St. Anne's located in Calumet Township on the early morning of the 11th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms forming ahead of strong low pressure system moving through Minnesota produced large hail over portions of Gogebic and Iron counties on the afternoon of the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail report was from the Gogebic County Sheriff's Office.   Time was estimated based on radar data.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms forming ahead of strong low pressure system moving through Minnesota produced large hail over portions of Gogebic and Iron counties on the afternoon of the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail between one-half inch to one inch in diameter was measured.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Northern Plains triggered thunderstorms with heavy rain over portions of western Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 30th. A severe thunderstorm produced wind gusts in excess of 60 mph at Freda in Houghton County.

A low pressure system approaching from the Northern Plains triggered thunderstorms with heavy rain over portions of western Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 30th. A severe thunderstorm produced wind gusts in excess of 60 mph at Freda in Houghton County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter southeast of Ontonagon measured 1.45 inches of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Northern Plains triggered thunderstorms with heavy rain over portions of western Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 30th. A severe thunderstorm produced wind gusts in excess of 60 mph at Freda in Houghton County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain over a 15-minute period caused two to three inches of water over roadways and flooding in ditches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A chilly north to northeast flow across Lake Superior produced moderate to heavy snow showers over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 11th into the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bergland received a reported eight inches of snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A chilly north to northeast flow across Lake Superior produced moderate to heavy snow showers over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 11th into the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters near Wakefield reported ten inches in 12 hours and 12 to 16 inches in the 24-hour period ending on the evening of the 12th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A chilly north to northeast flow across Lake Superior produced moderate to heavy snow showers over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 11th into the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Weather Service in Negaunee Township measured seven inches of snow in a 24-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into eastern Upper Michigan brought moderate to heavy snow and blowing snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 14th through the 15th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Rockland reported five inches of lake effect snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Northern Plains triggered thunderstorms with heavy rain over portions of western Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 30th. A severe thunderstorm produced wind gusts in excess of 60 mph at Freda in Houghton County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Freda measured 0.50 inches of rain in 15 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Northern Plains triggered thunderstorms with heavy rain over portions of western Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 30th. A severe thunderstorm produced wind gusts in excess of 60 mph at Freda in Houghton County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observer east of Chassell measured 1.25 inches of rain.  Most of the rain fell within a 15-minute period with rainfall rates of nearly 4 inches per hour recorded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Northern Plains triggered thunderstorms with heavy rain over portions of western Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 30th. A severe thunderstorm produced wind gusts in excess of 60 mph at Freda in Houghton County.

A low pressure system approaching from the Northern Plains triggered thunderstorms with heavy rain over portions of western Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 30th. A severe thunderstorm produced wind gusts in excess of 60 mph at Freda in Houghton County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds knocked down a 6-8 inch diameter tree and broke a flag pole in the yard.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into eastern Upper Michigan brought moderate to heavy snow and blowing snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 14th through the 15th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers at Garden Corners and near Rapid River measured 4 to 5 inches of snow in 12 hours.  Northwest winds gusting around 30 mph during the day on the 15th caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into eastern Upper Michigan brought moderate to heavy snow and blowing snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 14th through the 15th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Laurium measured six inches of snow in 15 hours while the observer in Twin Lakes measured five inches of snow in 12 hours.  North winds gusting over 25 mph at times caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow on the 15th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into eastern Upper Michigan brought moderate to heavy snow and blowing snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 14th through the 15th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Au Train received six inches of snow in 12 hours while the spotter near Grand Marais measured eight inches of snow in less than 24 hours.  North winds gusting around 30 mph at times also causing considerable blowing and drifting of snow on the 15th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into eastern Upper Michigan brought moderate to heavy snow and blowing snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 14th through the 15th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter snowfall reports for 24-hour period ending on the evening of the 15th included 11 inches near McMillan and 10 inches in Newberry.  North winds gusting around 30 mph at times also caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into eastern Upper Michigan brought moderate to heavy snow and blowing snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 14th through the 15th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Seney measured 15 inches of snow in 24 hours. North winds gusting around 30 mph at times caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Plains produced areas of moderate snow on the 17th and 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter in Menominee measured four inches of snow in six hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Northern Plains triggered thunderstorms with heavy rain over portions of western Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 30th. A severe thunderstorm produced wind gusts in excess of 60 mph at Freda in Houghton County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Gogebic County Sheriff reported a road washed out just west of Little Girls Point due to storms that passed over the area in the afternoon.  The road was closed from Little Girls Point west to the Wisconsin state line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced damaging wind gusts over Baraga and Alger Counties on the afternoon of the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter reported a 25-foot 10-inch diameter maple tree snapped.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced damaging wind gusts over Baraga and Alger Counties on the afternoon of the 31st.
Severe thunderstorms produced damaging wind gusts over Baraga and Alger Counties on the afternoon of the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell on power lines sparking a small fire on Imperial Heights Road just off of US-41.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced damaging wind gusts over Baraga and Alger Counties on the afternoon of the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous 100-foot white pine trees were downed along North Shore Road near Au Train Lake.  One tree fell over a power line, and a telephone pole was snapped in half.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Plains produced areas of moderate snow on the 17th and 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four inches of snow was reported in Hardwood along with occasionally low visibilities and slippery roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Plains produced areas of moderate snow on the 17th and 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated four to five inches of snow fell just east of Garden Corners in a 12-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Plains produced areas of moderate snow on the 17th and 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Silver City measured six inches of snow in a seven-hour period on the 17th and nine inches in the 24-hour period ending on the morning of the 18th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Plains produced areas of moderate snow on the 17th and 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Ironwood measured 8.6 inches of snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Northwest winds in the wake of a sharp cold frontal passage brought moderate to heavy lake effect snow for areas downwind of Lake Superior on the 20th and 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers in Eagle River and Mohawk reported moderate to heavy snow on the morning of the 20th and measured three to four inches of new snow in less than 6 hours.  North winds gusting over 30 mph also caused occasional whiteout conditions in snow and blowing snow from the 20th into the morning of the 21st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Northwest winds in the wake of a sharp cold frontal passage brought moderate to heavy lake effect snow for areas downwind of Lake Superior on the 20th and 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six-hour snowfall amounts of four inches or more were reported by spotters in Freda and Calumet on the morning of the 20th.  North to northwest winds gusting over 30 mph also caused occasional whiteout conditions in snow and blowing snow from the 20th into the morning of the 21st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Northwest winds in the wake of a sharp cold frontal passage brought moderate to heavy lake effect snow for areas downwind of Lake Superior on the 20th and 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Silver City reported moderate to occasionally heavy lake effect snow during the event with a 24-hour total of nine inches ending on the morning of the 21st.  The observer in Rockland also reported moderate to heavy lake effect snow and whiteout conditions in blowing snow on the 20th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Northwest winds in the wake of a sharp cold frontal passage brought moderate to heavy lake effect snow for areas downwind of Lake Superior on the 20th and 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter near Munising reported nearly three inches of lake effect snow in less than three hours. Gusty north winds to 30 mph also caused considerable blowing of snow and near whiteout conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Northwest winds in the wake of a sharp cold frontal passage brought moderate to heavy lake effect snow for areas downwind of Lake Superior on the 20th and 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter in Seney reported nearly four inches of snow in 18 hours.  North winds gusting to 30 mph also caused hazardous road conditions from considerable blowing and drifting of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another clipper low pressure system moved across the Upper Great Lakes generating moderate to heavy lake effect snow showers in its wake from the 22nd into the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter near Baraga estimated 8.5 inches of lake effect snow in only 8 hours. There was also a public report of very heavy snow in L'anse where an estimated five inches of snow fell in a two-hour period between noon and 2 pm EST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another clipper low pressure system moved across the Upper Great Lakes generating moderate to heavy lake effect snow showers in its wake from the 22nd into the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter near Harvey estimated four inches of very heavy lake effect snow between 430 pm and 630 pm on the 22nd.  A spotter near Carlshend measured seven inches of snow in less than 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another clipper low pressure system moved across the Upper Great Lakes generating moderate to heavy lake effect snow showers in its wake from the 22nd into the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to four inches of moderate to heavy snow fell in the Ironwood area between 2 pm and 630 pm CST on the 22nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another clipper low pressure system moved across the Upper Great Lakes generating moderate to heavy lake effect snow showers in its wake from the 22nd into the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters in Ontonagon and Silver City reported one inch per-hour snowfall rates on the afternoon of the 22nd with measured snowfall totals of three to five inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another clipper low pressure system moved across the Upper Great Lakes generating moderate to heavy lake effect snow showers in its wake from the 22nd into the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Mohawk reported greater than inch per-hour snowfall rates at times on the afternoon of the 22nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A clipper low pressure system moving down from south central Canada brought moderate to heavy snow to portions of west and south central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 28th into the morning of the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer west of Watersmeet measured eight inches of snow in less than six hours on the evening of the 28th.  There was another report of six inches of snow in five hours at Ironwood during the same time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Chilly west winds gradually veered to the west-northwest on the Northern Great Lakes.  That allowed a strong lake effect snow band on Lake Superior to pivot southward, moving inland into Eastern Upper Michigan.  Places between Strong and Paradise picked up six inches of snowfall in less than three hours.

A moisture-laden low pressure system moving from the mid-Mississippi Valley into the Great Lakes region dropped heavy snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 9th into the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated six inches of snow fell in less than 12 hours in Iron Mountain.  The combination of wet snow and north wind gusts to 30 mph caused numerous minor accidents and power outages across the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moisture-laden low pressure system moving from the mid-Mississippi Valley into the Great Lakes region dropped heavy snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 9th into the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight inches of snow fell in Sundell over an 11-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moisture-laden low pressure system moving from the mid-Mississippi Valley into the Great Lakes region dropped heavy snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 9th into the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around six inches of snow fell in a 24-hour period from Redridge to the Houghton-Hancock area.  The wet heavy snow and over 30 mph northerly wind gusts resulted in nine power outages in the Houghton area that affected more than 3500 residences.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moisture-laden low pressure system moving from the mid-Mississippi Valley into the Great Lakes region dropped heavy snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 9th into the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six inches of wet heavy snow fell northeast of Calumet in a 24-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moisture-laden low pressure system moving from the mid-Mississippi Valley into the Great Lakes region dropped heavy snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 9th into the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven to eight inches of snow fell in less than 24 hours near Wakefield and Watersmeet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moisture-laden low pressure system moving from the mid-Mississippi Valley into the Great Lakes region dropped heavy snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 9th into the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated eight inches of snowfall was reported near Paulding in less than 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moisture-laden low pressure system moving from the mid-Mississippi Valley into the Great Lakes region dropped heavy snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 9th into the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two inches of wet snow resulted in slick roadways across portions of southern Schoolcraft County on the afternoon and evening of the 9th.  The Schoolcraft County Sheriff reported three vehicular accidents due to the slippery roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A clipper low pressure system moving down from south central Canada brought moderate to heavy snow to portions of west and south central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 28th into the morning of the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread four to five inches fell across Iron County from the evening of the 28th into the overnight of the 29th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A clipper low pressure system moving down from south central Canada brought moderate to heavy snow to portions of west and south central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 28th into the morning of the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Norway measured four inches of snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A clipper low pressure system moving down from south central Canada brought moderate to heavy snow to portions of west and south central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 28th into the morning of the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Menominee measured 5.4 inches in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A clipper low pressure system moving down from south central Canada brought moderate to heavy snow to portions of west and south central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 28th into the morning of the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter near Copper Harbor reported five to six inches of snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow showers generated moderate snow accumulation for portions of Ontonagon County from the 29th into the 30th and heavy snow accumulation for portions of Alger County on the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer south of Silver City estimated six inches of snow in just over 12 hours.  There was also a report of five inches in 12 hours at White Pine.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow showers generated moderate snow accumulation for portions of Ontonagon County from the 29th into the 30th and heavy snow accumulation for portions of Alger County on the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A heavy lake effect snow band produced over one-inch per hour snowfall rates near Shingleton for much of the evening of the 31st.  Total snow accumulation in less than 12 hours was 8.7 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very chilly air mass in the wake of a strong cold frontal passage resulted in moderate to heavy lake effect snows off Lake Superior over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 16th into the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near South Range measured 12.5 inches of lake effect snow in 30 hours.  An estimated eight inches of snow fell in Calumet over a 12-hour period ending on the morning of the 17th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very chilly air mass in the wake of a strong cold frontal passage resulted in moderate to heavy lake effect snows off Lake Superior over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 16th into the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter ten miles east of Ontonagon estimated four inches of snow over a 12-hour period.  Strong winds caused blowing snow all day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very chilly air mass in the wake of a strong cold frontal passage resulted in moderate to heavy lake effect snows off Lake Superior over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 16th into the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter at Two Heart measured 11.5 inches of lake effect snow over a 36-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A clipper low pressure system moving down from south central Canada brought moderate to heavy snow to portions of west and south central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 28th into the morning of the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Silver City measured seven inches of snow in 24 hours, most of which fell on the evening of the 28th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A clipper low pressure system moving down from south central Canada brought moderate to heavy snow to portions of west and south central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 28th into the morning of the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Gladstone measured 3.1 inches of snow in nine hours.  The snow-covered and slippery highways contributed to a head-on collision on Highway US-2 in Ensign in the early morning hours of the 29th.  The Gladstone State Police reported that two elderly men suffered minor injuries in the crash.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake enhanced snowfall produced total snowfall accumulations of 6 to 8 inches in a 12 hour period across parts of the northern Thumb Region.|Here are a couple snowfall reports:|8 inches near Port Austin (Huron).|7 inches in Ubly (Huron).|6 inches in Minden (Sanilac).
A weakening clipper system brought generally two to five inches of snow to most of southeast Michigan, with around six inches falling in a 12 hour period just north of Bay city.

A low pressure system lifting from Wisconsin across eastern Lake Superior and then into Ontario brought periods of freezing rain and moderate snow to portions of Upper Michigan from the 16th into the 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Mohawk measured over seven inches of snow in 24 hours.  The spotter northeast of Calumet measured over 11 inches of snow in 19 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting from Wisconsin across eastern Lake Superior and then into Ontario brought periods of freezing rain and moderate snow to portions of Upper Michigan from the 16th into the 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Marenisco measured 5.5 inches of snow in less than 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting from Wisconsin across eastern Lake Superior and then into Ontario brought periods of freezing rain and moderate snow to portions of Upper Michigan from the 16th into the 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Gwinn measured five inches of snow in less than 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting from Wisconsin across eastern Lake Superior and then into Ontario brought periods of freezing rain and moderate snow to portions of Upper Michigan from the 16th into the 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Munising measured five inches of snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving in from Minnesota dropped moderate snow over portions of western Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread four to five inches of snow fell across the county in just over a 12-hour period.  Some greater than one-inch per hour snowfall rates were reported on the evening of the 22nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving in from Minnesota dropped moderate snow over portions of western Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearly four inches of snow fell in a 12-hour period at the National Weather Service in Negaunee Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving in from Minnesota dropped moderate snow over portions of western Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Alberta measured nearly four inches of wet snow in ten hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving in from Minnesota dropped moderate snow over portions of western Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Rockland measured three inches of wet snow in eight hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak disturbance moved through portions of lower Michigan and northern Indiana during the afternoon hours of the 26th. Sufficient instability and shear exist to allow for thunderstorms to develop and produce marginally severe hail and locally gusty winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported minor siding damage to a home. Several smaller branches were broken and a small shed was moved off of its foundation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak disturbance moved through portions of lower Michigan and northern Indiana during the afternoon hours of the 26th. Sufficient instability and shear exist to allow for thunderstorms to develop and produce marginally severe hail and locally gusty winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported quarter size hail falling in bursts. The hail was covering the ground in spots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving in from Minnesota dropped moderate snow over portions of western Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall amounts included 5.5 inches of snow near Alston and five inches near Redridge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak disturbance moved through portions of lower Michigan and northern Indiana during the afternoon hours of the 26th. Sufficient instability and shear exist to allow for thunderstorms to develop and produce marginally severe hail and locally gusty winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported hail ranging in size from pea to quarter size falling for four to five minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak disturbance moved through portions of lower Michigan and northern Indiana during the afternoon hours of the 26th. Sufficient instability and shear exist to allow for thunderstorms to develop and produce marginally severe hail and locally gusty winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported hail up to the size of quarters covering the ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak disturbance moved through portions of lower Michigan and northern Indiana during the afternoon hours of the 26th. Sufficient instability and shear exist to allow for thunderstorms to develop and produce marginally severe hail and locally gusty winds.

An intense low pressure system tracked from the Lower Mississippi River Valley northeast into northern Indiana late February 1st into February 2nd. Heavy snow developed out ahead of this system during the late afternoon and evening hours of February 1st, with many locations picking up between 6 and 10 inches of snow. This combined with wind gusts in excess of 40 mph created blizzard conditions across much of southwest Lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions were experienced during the late afternoon and evening hours of February 1st as an intense low pressure system approached from the southwest. Wind gusts in excess of 40 mph, combined with the falling heavy snow, created reduced visibilities below an eighth of a mile at times. Snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour were common, with totals across the county generally ranging between 6 and 9 inches. A CoCoRaHS observer reported 7.5 inches of total snow accumulation 6 miles east-northeast of Jonesville. Significant blowing and drifting snow resulted in numerous accidents and school closings across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm produced 1 inch hail near Milford.
A warm front lifting north produced a few strong to severe thunderstorms in and around Saginaw Bay.

An intense low pressure system tracked from the Lower Mississippi River Valley northeast into northern Indiana late February 1st into February 2nd. Heavy snow developed out ahead of this system during the late afternoon and evening hours of February 1st, with many locations picking up between 6 and 10 inches of snow. This combined with wind gusts in excess of 40 mph created blizzard conditions across much of southwest Lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions were experienced during the late afternoon and evening hours of February 1st as an intense low pressure system approached from the southwest. Wind gusts in excess of 40 mph, combined with the falling heavy snow, created reduced visibilities below an eighth of a mile at times. Snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour were common, with totals across the county generally ranging between 8 and 12 inches. A trained spotter in Benton Harbor reported 11.2 inches of total snow accumulation. Significant blowing and drifting snow resulted in numerous accidents and school closings across the region. There were also reports of road closures across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifting north produced a few strong to severe thunderstorms in and around Saginaw Bay.

Windy conditions occurred across lower Michigan on April 17 with peak wind gusts generally in the 40 to 45 mph range and a couple of isolated higher gusts to 47 mph.  These winds caused an isolated power outage in Eaton Rapids where a trained spotter reported that a large portion of the town lost power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter in Eaton Rapids reported that a significant portion of the town lost power during the early afternoon hours of April 17 due to strong winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved from Missouri to northern Indiana, spreading wintry precipitation into Northern Lower Michigan.  A mix of rain, freezing rain, and sleet, gradually turned to all snow on the night of the 4th, as cooler air filtered in from the north.  Accumulations of 3 to 6 inches were common in Northern Lower Michigan.  A small area of heavy snow, with 6 to 7 inches of accumulation, occurred in central and northern Roscommon County.

Strong low pressure moved east from Nebraska, passing just south of Michigan on the 23rd.  Heavy snow moved north into Northern Lower Michigan on the night of the 22nd, and persisted in spots into the afternoon of the 23rd.  Some mixed precipitation (mainly sleet, some freezing rain) made it as far north as the M-55 corridor during the night.  Snowfall totals ranged from 6 to 15 inches, with the highest amounts in parts of Leelanau and Grand Traverse Counties.

Low pressure moved across the southern Great Lakes early on the 20th, with cold air already in place across Northern Michigan. Precipitation type ranged from rain (and thunderstorms with small hail) near Gladwin, to sleet and then snow further north. A relatively narrow, east-west band of heavy snow fell from the Frankfort and Leland areas, eastward to Alpena.  Five to ten inches of sloppy, slushy snow fell in this band, with the highest amounts near Suttons Bay in Leelanau County.

An extended period of lake effect snow impacted Northwest Lower Michigan, from the 6th through the 9th.  Colder air entered the region on the 6th, behind a departing low pressure system.  A large upper low over Quebec gradually cycled back over the Great Lakes, helping to maintain lake effect snow for a lengthy period.  Wind directions changed substantially - from west-northwest to north-northeast and back to northwest - distributing the snow over a relatively large area.  Some of the higher snowfall totals included: 14 inches in Mancelona and 20 inches in Darragh by morning of the 7th; 19 inches in East Jordan and 24 inches in Bellaire by evening of the 7th; and 12 inches in Charlevoix on the day and night of the 7th-8th.

Strong winds which gusted to 35 to 45 mph across lower Michigan on April 15 caused a freak accident in Newaygo county, where an isolated 8 to 10 inch diameter tree was blown down onto a pickup truck, instantly killing the 60 year old driver.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Newaygo county official reported that high winds toppled an eight to ten inch diameter tree onto a pickup truck on M-20 east of White Cloud, instantly killing the 60 year old driver.

Strong low pressure moved from Texas, to northern Ohio, and on to the Northeast States, producing a large swath of heavy snow along the way.  Northern Lower Michigan caught the northern edge of the heavy snow swath.  Six to twelve inches of snow fell near and south of a line from Manistee, to Grayling, to Alpena.  The highest amounts fell in Arenac County, near Standish and Omer, where 13 to 14 inches of snowfall was reported.  The storm also produced very gusty easterly winds, resulting in considerable blowing and drifting snow.  Law enforcement in Au Gres reported blizzard conditions, with no visibility and a maximum safe driving speed of 5 mph.  An officer there described it as the worst conditions I've ever seen.  A spotter in Gladwin reported 4 to 5 foot drifts after the storm departed.

Arctic air flooding over the area in the wake of a cold frontal passage sustained a prolonged lake effect snow event from the evening of the 6th into the morning of the 10th.  During the event moderate snow fell over portions of western Upper Michigan while heavy snow fell in Alger County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter at Rockland measured 6.4 inches of snow in just over 12 hours.

A cold front crossed Northern Michigan early in the morning of the 18th. Gusty winds kicked in behind the front, and eventually lake effect snow did as well.  Though snow accumulations in Chippewa County were only 2 to 3 inches during the night of the 18th, winds gusted to 50 mph in many places, peaking at 61 mph near Bay Mills.  The combination of wind and snow produced near-blizzard conditions.  Elsewhere, wind gusts of 35 to 50 mph were common.  A spotter measured a 63 mph wind gust near Ossineke.
Several clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms moved onshore from central Lake Michigan into Northwest Lower Michigan.
Several clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms moved onshore from central Lake Michigan into Northwest Lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a pine tree, which toppled onto a home, and catching the home on fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms moved onshore from central Lake Michigan into Northwest Lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were measured to 79 mph at Manistee Harbor, and to 62 mph at Manistee Blacker Airport.  The most intense damage was in a localized, one square mile area, on the north side of downtown Manistee.  A pole building was destroyed, and there was damage to trees and shingles along Monroe Street.  Roofs and overhead doors were damaged in several commercial buildings along Glocheski Drive and Washington Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms moved onshore from central Lake Michigan into Northwest Lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large swath of trees was downed from the south side of Lake Missaukee near Goldenrod Road, east-northeast toward the intersection of South Morey Road and M-55/M-66.  Large pine trees were uprooted, or snapped off at mid-trunk.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level disturbance contributed to a second round of strong to severe thunderstorms across Northern Michigan.
A strong upper level disturbance contributed to a second round of strong to severe thunderstorms across Northern Michigan.

Strong low pressure moved east from Nebraska, passing just south of Michigan on the 23rd.  Heavy snow moved north into Northern Lower Michigan on the night of the 22nd, and persisted in spots into the afternoon of the 23rd.  Some mixed precipitation (mainly sleet, some freezing rain) made it as far north as the M-55 corridor during the night.  Snowfall totals ranged from 6 to 15 inches, with the highest amounts in parts of Leelanau and Grand Traverse Counties.

Strong low pressure moved east from Nebraska, passing just south of Michigan on the 23rd.  Heavy snow moved north into Northern Lower Michigan on the night of the 22nd, and persisted in spots into the afternoon of the 23rd.  Some mixed precipitation (mainly sleet, some freezing rain) made it as far north as the M-55 corridor during the night.  Snowfall totals ranged from 6 to 15 inches, with the highest amounts in parts of Leelanau and Grand Traverse Counties.

Arctic air flooding over the area in the wake of a cold frontal passage sustained a prolonged lake effect snow event from the evening of the 6th into the morning of the 10th.  During the event moderate snow fell over portions of western Upper Michigan while heavy snow fell in Alger County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Rockland measured 3.5 inches of snow in eight hours.  Slick roads and very low visibility were also reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: West winds turned west-northwest in the pre-dawn hours on the 9th.  That allowed pre-existing strong lake effect snow bands on Lake Superior to be brought onshore into western Chippewa County.  After that, a lengthy period of west-northwest winds allowed for occasional bouts of moderate to heavy lake effect snow.  Paradise picked up seven inches of snow by dawn on the 9th, and 24 hours later they had an event total of 14 inches.

A cold front crossed Northern Michigan early in the morning of the 18th. Gusty winds kicked in behind the front, and eventually lake effect snow did as well.  Though snow accumulations in Chippewa County were only 2 to 3 inches during the night of the 18th, winds gusted to 50 mph in many places, peaking at 61 mph near Bay Mills.  The combination of wind and snow produced near-blizzard conditions.  Elsewhere, wind gusts of 35 to 50 mph were common.  A spotter measured a 63 mph wind gust near Ossineke.
A low pressure system from the Northern Plains brought moderate snow to much of western Upper Michigan on the 3rd and 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Ironwood measured 3 inches of wet snow while 3.5 inches of snow fell just east of Wakefield.  The Gogebic County Sheriff reported very slick roads during this time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system from the Northern Plains brought moderate snow to much of western Upper Michigan on the 3rd and 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter west of Iron River measured a quick two inches of wet, heavy snow in less than 4 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system from the Northern Plains brought moderate snow to much of western Upper Michigan on the 3rd and 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer northeast of Alberta measured 3.7 inches of wet snow in less than 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system from the Northern Plains brought moderate snow to much of western Upper Michigan on the 3rd and 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated three to four inches of wet snow fell across much of southern Houghton County in less than 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system from the Northern Plains brought moderate snow to much of western Upper Michigan on the 3rd and 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers measured five to six inches of wet snow from near Ontonagon to Rockland.  Slick roads were also reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air flooding over the area in the wake of a cold frontal passage sustained a prolonged lake effect snow event from the evening of the 6th into the morning of the 10th.  During the event moderate snow fell over portions of western Upper Michigan while heavy snow fell in Alger County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement estimated four to five inches of snow in Bessemer in just over a 12-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm moist southerly flow of air ahead of an approaching cold front and across an existing snow pack resulted in dense fog over portions of central and eastern Upper Michigan on the 17th and the early morning of the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibilities were reduced to one-quarter mile or less at times in dense fog.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level disturbance contributed to a second round of strong to severe thunderstorms across Northern Michigan.
A strong upper level disturbance contributed to a second round of strong to severe thunderstorms across Northern Michigan.
A strong upper level disturbance contributed to a second round of strong to severe thunderstorms across Northern Michigan.
A strong upper level disturbance contributed to a second round of strong to severe thunderstorms across Northern Michigan.
A low pressure system from the Northern Plains brought moderate snow to much of western Upper Michigan on the 3rd and 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall amounts included 9.5 inches near Painesdale...9 inches near Red Ridge and 7 inches near Calumet.  Periods of freezing drizzle were also reported at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting from Wisconsin across eastern Lake Superior and then into Ontario brought periods of freezing rain and moderate snow to portions of Upper Michigan from the 16th into the 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers from Newberry to Two Heart measured from 0.10 inch to 0.30 inch of freezing rain on the morning of the 16th.  The Luce County Sheriff reported a widespread glaze on elevated surfaces as ice accumulation caused minor damage to tree limbs.  One broken tree limb fell on a power line and started a fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm moist southerly flow of air ahead of an approaching cold front and across an existing snow pack resulted in dense fog over portions of central and eastern Upper Michigan on the 17th and the early morning of the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dense fog reduced visibility to one-quarter mile or less at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm moist southerly flow of air ahead of an approaching cold front and across an existing snow pack resulted in dense fog over portions of central and eastern Upper Michigan on the 17th and the early morning of the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dense fog reduced visibility to one-quarter mile or less over portions of Marquette County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dense fog reduced visibility to one-quarter mile or less at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting from Wisconsin across eastern Lake Superior and then into Ontario brought periods of freezing rain and moderate snow to portions of Upper Michigan from the 16th into the 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Gladstone measured 0.20 of an inch of freezing rain on the morning of the 16th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting from Wisconsin across eastern Lake Superior and then into Ontario brought periods of freezing rain and moderate snow to portions of Upper Michigan from the 16th into the 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Rockland measured 3.5 inches of wet snow in 12 hours with one inch per-hour rates at times.  The observer southwest of Ontonagon measured five inches of snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting from Wisconsin across eastern Lake Superior and then into Ontario brought periods of freezing rain and moderate snow to portions of Upper Michigan from the 16th into the 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers in Watton and near Alberta measured 24-hour snowfall amounts of 6.6 inches and 6.4 inches respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting from Wisconsin across eastern Lake Superior and then into Ontario brought periods of freezing rain and moderate snow to portions of Upper Michigan from the 16th into the 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers near Chassell and Twin Lakes measured around 6.5 inches of snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong west winds in the wake of a powerful cold front resulted in downed trees and power lines over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan on the 18th.  Lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow also resulted in blizzard conditions over the Keweenaw Peninsula.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility was one-quarter mile or less in snow and blowing snow from late morning into mid-afternoon as winds frequently gusted over 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong west winds in the wake of a powerful cold front resulted in downed trees and power lines over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan on the 18th.  Lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow also resulted in blizzard conditions over the Keweenaw Peninsula.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility was one-quarter mile or less in snow and blowing snow from late morning into mid-afternoon as winds frequently gusted over 55 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong west winds in the wake of a powerful cold front resulted in downed trees and power lines over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan on the 18th.  Lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow also resulted in blizzard conditions over the Keweenaw Peninsula.

Strong west winds in the wake of a powerful cold front resulted in downed trees and power lines over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan on the 18th.  Lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow also resulted in blizzard conditions over the Keweenaw Peninsula.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extensive damage to power lines was reported in the village of Ontonagon due to the high winds.  The Upper Peninsula Power Company reported nearly 150 customers without power into the afternoon of the 19th as relief crews had to be called in from central Wisconsin to help restore full power.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong west winds in the wake of a powerful cold front resulted in downed trees and power lines over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan on the 18th.  Lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow also resulted in blizzard conditions over the Keweenaw Peninsula.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The GLOS at Grand Marais measured wind gusts to 65 mph during the event. The high winds downed trees and caused some sporadic power outages for communities along the Lake Superior shoreline.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong west winds in the wake of a powerful cold front resulted in downed trees and power lines over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan on the 18th.  Lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow also resulted in blizzard conditions over the Keweenaw Peninsula.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be over 60 mph caused downed trees and sporadic power outages...mainly for communities along the Lake Superior shoreline.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An extended period of lake effect snow impacted Northwest Lower Michigan, from the 6th through the 9th.  Colder air entered the region on the 6th, behind a departing low pressure system.  A large upper low over Quebec gradually cycled back over the Great Lakes, helping to maintain lake effect snow for a lengthy period.  Wind directions changed substantially - from west-northwest to north-northeast and back to northwest - distributing the snow over a relatively large area.  Some of the higher snowfall totals included: 14 inches in Mancelona and 20 inches in Darragh by morning of the 7th; 19 inches in East Jordan and 24 inches in Bellaire by evening of the 7th; and 12 inches in Charlevoix on the day and night of the 7th-8th.

Low pressure tracked across Indiana and Ohio on the night of the 20th.  Northern Michigan would be on the northern fringe of the heavy snow swath.  Snowfall amounts of 6 to 7 inches were common near and south of the M-55 corridor, dwindling to much less to the north.  The highest amount, 8.2 inches, fell near Wellston.  Northeast winds gusted up to 30 mph, resulting in some blowing and drifting snow.

Severe thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon and evening hours of April 26 as an upper level trough and cold front approached our region.  Several low topped supercells developed and produced numerous reports of large hail up to around two inches in diameter.  In addition a damage survey team from the NWS Grand Rapids office determined that damage caused near Burnips in Allegan County was due to an EF-0 tornado with top winds near 85 mph that damaged buildings at the Deboer Turkey Farm and trailers around the area.  In Portage, nine people were injured by a lightning strike.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter in southern Kent county reported seeing a brief funnel cloud three to five miles south of the M-6 and Kalamazoo Avenue intersection.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon and evening hours of April 26 as an upper level trough and cold front approached our region.  Several low topped supercells developed and produced numerous reports of large hail up to around two inches in diameter.  In addition a damage survey team from the NWS Grand Rapids office determined that damage caused near Burnips in Allegan County was due to an EF-0 tornado with top winds near 85 mph that damaged buildings at the Deboer Turkey Farm and trailers around the area.  In Portage, nine people were injured by a lightning strike.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado touchdown at a landscaping company where it tore a small section of roof of a warehouse building, knocked over several trailers, and blew the windows out of several cars.  The tornado then struck a row of 100 yard long turkey pole barns.  An approximately 100 ft section of one barn was uplifted and the collapsed. The roof was torn off about a 50 ft section of another barn.  Further northeast, several small outbuildings were destroyed and trees were uprooted.  Several houses in the path received minor roof and soffit damage with two garage doors damaged.  The tornado lifted after partially destroying a 75 year-old 40 ft by 90 ft barn.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system tracked through the Western Great Lakes, allowing a strong warm front to lift north into Southeast Michigan, resulting in a mixed bag of precipitation. Mostly snow fell north of I-69, snow and ice along I-69 and M-59 corridors, with mostly rain south of M-59. Power outages along with scattered downed trees and large limbs were reported along the I-69 corridor. Here are the highest snowfall totals reported, along with ice accumulations:||Midland (Midland), 8 inches.|Bentley (Bay), 8 inches.|Lapeer (Lapeer),  8 inches.|Bad Axe (Huron), 7 inches.|Richmond (Macomb), 6.5 inches, glazing of ice.|Marlette (Sanilac), 6.5 inches, glazing of ice.|Capac (St. Clair) 6.5 inches, glazing of ice.|Fairgrove (Tuscola), 6 inches.|Saginaw (Saginaw) 6 inches, tenth of an inch of ice.|Burton (Genesee), 5 inches, tenth to two tenths of ice.|Corunna (Shiawassee) 3 inches, tenth to two tenths of ice.|Algonac (St. Clair) 1.5 inches, quarter inch of ice.

Severe thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon and evening hours of April 26 as an upper level trough and cold front approached our region.  Several low topped supercells developed and produced numerous reports of large hail up to around two inches in diameter.  In addition a damage survey team from the NWS Grand Rapids office determined that damage caused near Burnips in Allegan County was due to an EF-0 tornado with top winds near 85 mph that damaged buildings at the Deboer Turkey Farm and trailers around the area.  In Portage, nine people were injured by a lightning strike.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nine people were injured when lightning struck a soccer field in Portage at Westfield Park.  The injured were a mix of adults and students who ranged in age from 12 to 41.  Seven people were transported to area hospitals and two sought treatment on their own.  One man who was injured most seriously went into cardiac arrest before being treated and released from Bronson hospital in Kalamazoo.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A big winter storm impacted southeast Michigan, with 5 to 10 inches of snow falling across the majority of the area. Snow turned to ice near the Ohio border, where a major ice storm occured. Downed trees and powerlines occured over Lenawee and Monroe counties due to ice accumulations half an inch to one inch.  Power outages lasted 4 to 5 days.

An incoming warm triggered a few strong to severe thunderstorms in Central Lower Michigan.
An incoming warm triggered a few strong to severe thunderstorms in Central Lower Michigan.

Several days of significant rainfall resulted in localized flooding in northern Cheboygan County.  Inverness Trail was washed out near Maynard Road.  Numerous other secondary and gravel roads were washed out and closed.  Water levels reached the sides of a few homes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Inverness Trail was washed out near Maynard Road. Numerous other secondary and gravel roads were washed out and closed. Water levels reached the sides of a few homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An incoming warm triggered a few strong to severe thunderstorms in Central Lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was downed across a road, shingles were removed from a few homes, a steel carport was blown down, and a shed was moved about 40 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe storm moved through Monroe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree limbs were reported down, along with roof shingles and siding off a house.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe storm moved through Monroe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were closed due to flooding from heavy showers and thundertorms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated marginally severe storm collapsed near Commerce producing severe winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four inch diameter tree limbs were reported down near the intersection of Cooley Lake and Carroll Lake Roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter in Ovid reported that a severe thunderstorm produced one inch diameter hail and that several tree branches were also blown down.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One inch diameter hail was reported by a trained spotter in Ovid.  The radar maximum estimated hail size algorithm suggests that one inch diameter most likely fell from just southwest of Ovid northeast to northern Ovid.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening mainly produced brief heavy rainfall and frequent lightning, but a couple of storms did produce hail of up to three quarters of an inch to an inch and a half in diameter.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter three miles north northwest of Wheeler reported that a severe thunderstorm produced hail that was predominately dime sized, but also some nickel sized hail and even a few hailstones which were up to an inch and a half in diameter.  The larger stones may have stuck together on the ground after falling.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter two miles north northwest of Dimondale reported that hail ranging from pea sized to nickel (three quarters inch diameter) fell for three minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two to four inches of rain fell along the I-94 corridor leading to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous streets and homes flooded across the county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter measured a 62 mph thunderstorm wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front worked north into portions of far southern lower Michigan during the late morning hours. A line of severe thunderstorms developed in eastern Iowa and moved rapidly east into Indiana. Initially the storms were sub severe as they moved across Lake Michigan but quickly organized and became severe as they entered St. Joseph county. An area of wind damage occurred across St. Joseph county with a brief tornado touched down in Coldwater in Branch county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A survey of damage was conducted in the Coldwater area. The damage found was consistent with a brief tornado touchdown within an area of wind damage around the touchdown location. The circulation touched down near U.S. 12 and Interstate 69, at 364 South Michigan Avenue. Major roof damage to a storage facility occurred, along with substantial tree damage. The garage door on the east side of a house was blown in just south of Woodward Drive.  The tornado passed across Interstate 69 depositing debris on portions of the Interstate, causing brief lane closures. The damage was consistent with an EF1 with winds of around 90 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two lifting mechanisms, a cold front and a lake breeze, interacted with an extremely unstable, but poorly sheared environment, to allow for thunderstorm development. The highest instability resided south into Indiana and Ohio, limiting the coverage and intensity of the storms across far southern Lower Michigan. Two  reports of quarter size hail were received.

A tight pressure gradient with high pressure to the north and low pressure to the south, coupled with funneling through Saginaw Bay lead to strong northeast winds in excess of 55 mph across Bay and Saginaw Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous large tree limbs and trees reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tight pressure gradient with high pressure to the north and low pressure to the south, coupled with funneling through Saginaw Bay lead to strong northeast winds in excess of 55 mph across Bay and Saginaw Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees and powerlines were reported blown down across roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike caused a barn to catch fire, destroying the barn. A tractor was also inside the barn and was destroyed.
An isolated severe thunderstorm tracked east southeast across northern Ingham county, producing a measured wind gust of 59 mph just north northwest of Lake Lansing near Haslett.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Radar data corroborated a 59 mph measured wind gust just north northwest of Lake Lansing near Haslett.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm just southwest of Medina produced 1 inch hail.
A thunderstorm just southwest of Medina produced 1 inch hail.

A winter storm impacted most of Southwest Lower Michigan from near Interstate 96 northward from late afternoon of March 22nd into the early afternoon hours of March 23rd.  Areas north and east of a line from Baldwin to Alma had between 6 and 12 inches of snow.  North of Interstate 96 northward there was a significant amount of ice accumulation from freezing rain and sleet that fell during the night into the morning. Numerous accidents were reported and there were numerous school closings.  Power outages were common on the morning of the 23rd due to downed power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tenth to nearly a quarter of an inch of ice accumulation occurred across the eastern half of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow developed on January 6th and continued over portions of the area through January 8th.  The snow showers were triggered by an Alberta Clipper that tracked north of the area on Jan 6th.  West-northwesterly flow brought widespread snow showers and 2 to 6 inches of snow to most areas west of Route 131 on the 6th into the 7th.  Winds then became more northwest midday on the 7th with heavier snow showers bringing locally a foot of snow to interior Mason County and the southwest corner of Van Buren County.  Local three day snowfall totals exceeded 18 inches. Numerous accidents were reported along US-31 and US-131 on the 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A CoCoRaHs observer six miles southwest of Kalamazoo measured 7.3 inches of snow from the 6th through 8 a.m. on the 9th.   Total snow accumulations countywide ranged from 5 to 8 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ice accumulations between 0.25 and 0.50 impacted portions of southern Michigan as a steady freezing rain fell north of a stalled out frontal boundary during the afternoon and evening hours of February 20th. The freezing rain finally tapered off during the early morning hours of February 21st, leaving power outages and icy roads in its wake.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain developed around noon on February 20th and continued through the rest of the day into the early morning hours of February 21st. Ice accretions of 0.30 to 0.50 were common across the county.  This created significant icing on power lines and trees which led to widespread power outages across the county. There were also reports of slide-offs and accidents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from the Plains toward eastern Upper Michigan dumped heavy wet snow over portions of western Upper Michigan on the 3rd and 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters at Herman and near Sidnaw measured five inches of wet heavy snow in just over 12 hours. Several accidents were reported in the L'anse area due to slippery roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from the Plains toward eastern Upper Michigan dumped heavy wet snow over portions of western Upper Michigan on the 3rd and 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter nine miles southwest of Big Bay measured seven inches of wet heavy snow in a 14-hour period.  Five to six inches of snow were also reported from Negaunee to Ishpeming.  Sporadic power outages were reported due to the heavy wet snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from the Plains toward eastern Upper Michigan dumped heavy wet snow over portions of western Upper Michigan on the 3rd and 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters from Calumet to Mohawk measured 6 to 7 inches of wet heavy snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from the Plains toward eastern Upper Michigan dumped heavy wet snow over portions of western Upper Michigan on the 3rd and 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters near Twin Lakes, Chassell, Jacobsville, Houghton and Calumet measured a widespread 7 to 8 inches of wet, heavy snow in a 12-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from the Plains toward eastern Upper Michigan dumped heavy wet snow over portions of western Upper Michigan on the 3rd and 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A fairly widespread 7 to 8 inches of wet heavy snow fell over a 12-hour period across much of Ontonagon County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air flooding over the area in the wake of a cold frontal passage sustained a prolonged lake effect snow event from the evening of the 6th into the morning of the 10th.  During the event moderate snow fell over portions of western Upper Michigan while heavy snow fell in Alger County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Twin Lakes measured eight inches of snow in 24 hours. Northwest winds gusting to 30 mph also contributed to considerable blowing of snow and reduced visibility at times.

A low pressure trough passing over the Upper Great Lakes caused heavy lake effect snow over the Keweenaw Peninsula on the 1st and 2nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers in Mohawk and Eagle River reported around a foot of snow in 24 hours with some blowing and drifting of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure trough passing over the Upper Great Lakes caused heavy lake effect snow over the Keweenaw Peninsula on the 1st and 2nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters near Houghton measured 12-hour snowfall amounts of eight inches while also  reported blowing and drifting of snow into the afternoon of the 2nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced one to three inches of rainfall over three to six hours.  The heavy rain combined with melting snow to produce flash flooding of small creeks and streams from Hesperia in Oceana County east-northeast through central Mecosta County and into western Isabella County.  The flooding washed out multiple roads and flooded one trailer park.  The storms also produced pea sized hail. ||The thunderstorms developed ahead of an approaching low pressure system and the intersection of a warm and cold front. The storms initially formed along and east-west line from near Muskegon to Mount Pleasant.  That line remained relatively stationary while a second cluster of thunderstorms moved across Lake Michigan and merged with the line during the early morning hours on Monday.  The storms then moved east of the affected area by daybreak Monday.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A local State of Emergency was declared for Mecosta County as a result of extensive heavy rainfall and melting snow during the early morning hours of April 4, 2011, causing widespread flood damage to public and individual property.  Numerous roads were washed out and/or covered with water.  A significant thoroughfare, M-20, was temporarily closed when overflow from Schrader Creek resulted in 6 inches of moving water over the road.  Over a dozen homes along Harding Road and 17 Mile were surrounded by water, with several homes with water up to their foundations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of clipper low pressure systems moving through the region helped generate moderate to heavy lake effect snow showers downwind of Lake Superior in a northwest to north flow from the 6th into the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter three miles south of Grand Marais reported ten inches of lake effect snow in a 15-hour period with visibilities dropping to one-quarter mile at times.  The 36-hour storm total snowfall was 18 inches at the same site.  The spotter at Melstrand reported a three-day storm total snowfall of 25 inches ending on the morning of the 9th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon and evening hours of April 19th in an axis of increasing elevated instability well to the north of a warm front across Indiana and Ohio.  The storms produced numerous reports of hail across southern lower Michigan.  Most of the hail was sub severe, but there were a couple of reports of hail reaching an inch to an inch and a quarter in diameter.  The thunderstorms were also accompanied by heavy rainfall and frequent lightning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter just northeast of Jamestown reported that hail sizes ranged from a half an inch to three quarters of an inch in diameter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm impacted most of Southwest Lower Michigan from near Interstate 96 northward from late afternoon of March 22nd into the early afternoon hours of March 23rd.  Areas north and east of a line from Baldwin to Alma had between 6 and 12 inches of snow.  North of Interstate 96 northward there was a significant amount of ice accumulation from freezing rain and sleet that fell during the night into the morning. Numerous accidents were reported and there were numerous school closings.  Power outages were common on the morning of the 23rd due to downed power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters in and near Mt. Pleasant reported storm total snowfall of seven to seven and a half inches, and portions of northern Isabella county received approximately eight to nine inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air flooding over the area in the wake of a cold frontal passage sustained a prolonged lake effect snow event from the evening of the 6th into the morning of the 10th. Nearly nine inches of additional snow fell in the 24-hour period ending on the morning of the 10th.  The Melstrand observer also reported periods of heavy snow on the afternoon of the 9th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong west winds in the wake of a powerful cold front resulted in downed trees and power lines over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan on the 18th.  Lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow also resulted in blizzard conditions over the Keweenaw Peninsula.

Strong west winds in the wake of a powerful cold front resulted in downed trees and power lines over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan on the 18th.  Lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow also resulted in blizzard conditions over the Keweenaw Peninsula.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds caused trees to fall on power lines resulting in power outages to approximately 2,000 customers in Marquette County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with hail developed during the early morning hours of April 10 across central lower Michigan.  An isolated severe thunderstorm near Wolf Lake produced one inch diameter hail.  Several other non severe thunderstorms in the vicinity of Route 10 produced hail of up to half an inch in diameter.  The thunderstorms developed in an axis of strong elevated instability north of a warm front that lifted north across southern and central lower Michigan overnight.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement near Wolf Lake reported hail the size of a quarter (one inch) in diameter.

The thunderstorms were also accompanied by heavy rainfall and frequent lightning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to nickel sized hail was reported by a trained spotter near Charlotte.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm impacted southeast Michigan, with snowfall accumulations generally ranging from 6 to 12 inches. Isolated higher amounts were recorded across the Thumb and Tri-Cities Region. Northeast winds gusting between 25 to 35 mph caused some blowing and drifting of snow. A major winter storm impacted southeast Michigan, with snowfall accumulations generally ranging from 6 to 12 inches. Isolated higher amounts were recorded across the Thumb and Tri-Cities Region. Northeast winds gusting between 25 to 35 mph caused some blowing and drifting of snow. Frequent wind gusts to 35 mph came off Lake Huron and Saginaw Bay, leading to blizzard conditions north of the I-69 corridor.||Here are some higher snowfall reports across the area:||Pigeon (Huron), 14 inches.|Port Huron (St. Clair) 14 inches.|Lapeer (Lapeer), 13.6 inches.|Lexington (Sanilac), 13.5 inches.|Bridgeport (Saginaw) 13 inches.|Mayville (Tuscola) 13 inches.|Pinconning (Bay), 12 inches.|Flushing (Genesee), 11 inches.|Lake Orion (Oakland), 10 inches.|Romulus (Wayne), 9 inches.|Dexter (Washtenaw), 8.5 inches.|Ray Center (Macomb), 8.2 inches.|Corunna (Shiawassee) 8 inches.|Tecumseh (Monroe), 7 inches.|Howell (Livingston), 6.2 inches.|Monroe (Monroe), 6 inches.

Lake enhanced snow caused numerous traffic accidents and temporary highway closures across parts of Muskegon, Ottawa and Kent counties including the Grand Rapids metro area.  A new daily snowfall record was set in Muskegon, where 10.7 inches of snow was measured. The heavy snow was localized to Muskegon and Ottawa Counties where snowfall rates exceeded one inch per hour during the morning hours.  Elsewhere three to six inches of snow fell across parts of Allegan, Kent, Oceana, Newaygo, and Mason Counties. The snow occurred in west-southwesterly flow associated with a clipper system that passed by to the north on the 22nd.  Cold temperatures in the teens and wind chills near zero during the event also contributed to the hazardous road conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A CoCoRaHS observer reported nine inches of snow fell five miles northwest of Holland.  The heaviest snow falling in the morning. Numerous traffic accidents were reported on I-196 near Grandville in eastern Ottawa county, which caused that section of I-196 to be closed for several hours during the late morning and early afternoon.  Wind chills near zero exacerbated the hazardous weather conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm brought heavy wet snow from Holland to Lansing and points north during the afternoon and evening hours of Sunday, February 20th.  South of those areas up to three quarters of an inch of freezing rain.  There were numerous accidents including a sixty car pile-up on Route 131 near Big Rapids.  More than one-hundred thousand people lost power along the Interstate 94 corridor where the freezing rain was the most severe. The storm responsible for the snow and ice was located over eastern South Dakota Sunday morning. The storm center then tracked east moving along the Michigan and Indiana border Sunday night before redeveloping off the Mid-Atlantic Coast on Monday.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight to twelve inches of snow fell across the county. Snowfall rates of one to two inches per hour occurred during the first few hours of the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon and evening hours of April 19th in an axis of increasing elevated instability well to the north of a warm front across Indiana and Ohio.  The storms produced numerous reports of hail across southern lower Michigan.  Most of the hail was sub severe, but there were a couple of reports of hail reaching an inch to an inch and a quarter in diameter.  The thunderstorms were also accompanied by heavy rainfall and frequent lightning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement in Moline reported three-quarter inch diameter hail.
