EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon and evening hours of April 26 as an upper level trough and cold front approached our region.  Several low topped supercells developed and produced numerous reports of large hail up to around two inches in diameter.  In addition a damage survey team from the NWS Grand Rapids office determined that damage caused near Burnips in Allegan County was due to an EF-0 tornado with top winds near 85 mph that damaged buildings at the Deboer Turkey Farm and trailers around the area.  In Portage, nine people were injured by a lightning strike.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported  hail up to 1.5 inches in diameter south of Stanton and just north of Sheridan.  The swath was up to one mile wide and was part of the swath that began in extreme northeast Ottawa County based on correlation with multiple spotter reports and radar hail products.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon and evening hours of April 26 as an upper level trough and cold front approached our region.  Several low topped supercells developed and produced numerous reports of large hail up to around two inches in diameter.  In addition a damage survey team from the NWS Grand Rapids office determined that damage caused near Burnips in Allegan County was due to an EF-0 tornado with top winds near 85 mph that damaged buildings at the Deboer Turkey Farm and trailers around the area.  In Portage, nine people were injured by a lightning strike.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported that large hail fell from a thunderstorm that tracked from just southwest of Oshtemo east northeast across northern Kalamazoo to Richland.  The hail size reached 1.25 inches in diameter two miles west of Richland. The hail swath was up to one mile wide based on the correlation of spotter reports with WSR-88D radar products.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon and evening hours of April 26 as an upper level trough and cold front approached our region.  Several low topped supercells developed and produced numerous reports of large hail up to around two inches in diameter.  In addition a damage survey team from the NWS Grand Rapids office determined that damage caused near Burnips in Allegan County was due to an EF-0 tornado with top winds near 85 mph that damaged buildings at the Deboer Turkey Farm and trailers around the area.  In Portage, nine people were injured by a lightning strike.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail up to  1.5 inches in diameter fell in a half mile wide swath beginning southwest of Cutlerville and continuing northeast through Ada. Some of the largest hail was observed at the Grand Rapids Weather Forecast Office.  The swath was estimated based on the correlation of multiple spotter reports with maximum estimated hail size, NSSL hail swath track algorithm, and 0.5 degree reflectivity products form WFO-GRR WSR88D.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A big winter storm impacted southeast Michigan, with 5 to 10 inches of snow falling across the majority of the area. Snow turned to ice near the Ohio border, where a major ice storm occured. Downed trees and powerlines occured over Lenawee and Monroe counties due to ice accumulations half an inch to one inch.  Power outages lasted 4 to 5 days.

A series of clipper low pressure systems moving through the region helped generate moderate to heavy lake effect snow showers downwind of Lake Superior in a northwest to north flow from the 6th into the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter reports of 12-hour snowfall ending on the morning of the 8th included 11 inches at Mass City and 8 inches at White Pine.  A spotter in Ontonagon also reported a whopping six inches of snow in just two hours during the early morning on the 8th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Around a tenth to an eighth of an inch of freezing rain began during the early morning hours across portions of central lower Michigan and quickly resulted in a glaze of ice on area roads, resulting in numerous accidents.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Media from the Lansing area reported that icy roads due to freezing rain during the early morning hours caused twenty to thirty cars to go in a ditch east of Okemos on I-96.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Around a tenth to an eighth of an inch of freezing rain began during the early morning hours across portions of central lower Michigan and quickly resulted in a glaze of ice on area roads, resulting in numerous accidents.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A county official from Lake county reported that freezing rain began around 6 a.m. and caused a quick glaze of icy to develop on everything.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Around a tenth to an eighth of an inch of freezing rain began during the early morning hours across portions of central lower Michigan and quickly resulted in a glaze of ice on area roads, resulting in numerous accidents.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A co-op observer three miles west southwest of Hart reported a tenth of an inch of ice accumulation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system advancing from the Northern Plains brought periods of wet heavy snow to portions of western Upper Michigan on the 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters near Marenisco measured four to five inches of wet snow in the early morning hours of the 20th.  Greater than one inch per-hour snowfall rates occurred over a three-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system advancing from the Northern Plains brought periods of wet heavy snow to portions of western Upper Michigan on the 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of three inches of wet snow in Calumet during the late afternoon and evening hours of the 20th.  The Houghton County Airport also reported lowered visibility in moderate to heavy snow during the event.

A major winter storm brought 10 to 15 inches of snow and blizzard conditions to much of southwest lower Michigan the during the late evening of Tuesday, February 1st into the morning hours of Wednesday, February 2nd.  Wind gusts in excess of 40 mph combined with heavy snow to produce whiteout conditions and snowdrifts of 3 to 5 feet.  Thunder accompanied the snow in some areas with snowfall rates exceeding two inches per hour. Many businesses, schools, and some government offices were closed on Wednesday.  Most main roads were plowed by midday Wednesday but some side streets were not cleared until Thursday. The storm is considered a 1 in 10 year event for south west Michigan.  The storm also brought blizzard conditions to parts of Kansas, Missouri, Iowa, Illinois, Wisconsin, New York, Vermont, New Hampshire, and Maine.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions began during the evening hours Tuesday, February 1st and continued into the early morning hours on Wednesday. Fourteen to twenty inches of snow were reported across the county. Winds gusts up to 50 mph accompanied 1 to 2 inch hourly snowfall rates.  Snow drifts of 3 to 5 feet occurred in open areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm brought heavy wet snow from Holland to Lansing and points north during the afternoon and evening hours of Sunday, February 20th.  South of those areas up to three quarters of an inch of freezing rain.  There were numerous accidents including a sixty car pile-up on Route 131 near Big Rapids.  More than one-hundred thousand people lost power along the Interstate 94 corridor where the freezing rain was the most severe. The storm responsible for the snow and ice was located over eastern South Dakota Sunday morning. The storm center then tracked east moving along the Michigan and Indiana border Sunday night before redeveloping off the Mid-Atlantic Coast on Monday.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ice accumulations of one-quarter to one-half of an inch occurred over the northwest areas of the county.  The ice was preceded by 1 to 3 inches of a snow-sleet mixture.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm brought heavy wet snow from Holland to Lansing and points north during the afternoon and evening hours of Sunday, February 20th.  South of those areas up to three quarters of an inch of freezing rain.  There were numerous accidents including a sixty car pile-up on Route 131 near Big Rapids.  More than one-hundred thousand people lost power along the Interstate 94 corridor where the freezing rain was the most severe. The storm responsible for the snow and ice was located over eastern South Dakota Sunday morning. The storm center then tracked east moving along the Michigan and Indiana border Sunday night before redeveloping off the Mid-Atlantic Coast on Monday.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ice accumulations of one-quarter to one-half of an inch occurred over the county. The ice was preceded by 2 to 4 inches of a snow-sleet mixture.  Approximately forty-five thousand people lost power during the storm.  It took up to five days to restore power.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm impacted southeast Michigan, with snowfall accumulations generally ranging from 6 to 12 inches. Isolated higher amounts were recorded across the Thumb and Tri-Cities Region. Northeast winds gusting between 25 to 35 mph caused some blowing and drifting of snow. Frequent wind gusts to 35 mph came off Lake Huron and Saginaw Bay, leading to blizzard conditions north of the I-69 corridor.||Here are some higher snowfall reports across the area:||Pigeon (Huron), 14 inches.|Port Huron (St. Clair) 14 inches.|Lapeer (Lapeer), 13.6 inches.|Lexington (Sanilac), 13.5 inches.|Bridgeport (Saginaw) 13 inches.|Mayville (Tuscola) 13 inches.|Pinconning (Bay), 12 inches.|Flushing (Genesee), 11 inches.|Lake Orion (Oakland), 10 inches.|Romulus (Wayne), 9 inches.|Dexter (Washtenaw), 8.5 inches.|Ray Center (Macomb), 8.2 inches.|Corunna (Shiawassee) 8 inches.|Tecumseh (Monroe), 7 inches.|Howell (Livingston), 6.2 inches.|Monroe (Monroe), 6 inches.

A major winter storm brought 10 to 15 inches of snow and blizzard conditions to much of southwest lower Michigan the during the late evening of Tuesday, February 1st into the morning hours of Wednesday, February 2nd.  Wind gusts in excess of 40 mph combined with heavy snow to produce whiteout conditions and snowdrifts of 3 to 5 feet.  Thunder accompanied the snow in some areas with snowfall rates exceeding two inches per hour. Many businesses, schools, and some government offices were closed on Wednesday.  Most main roads were plowed by midday Wednesday but some side streets were not cleared until Thursday. The storm is considered a 1 in 10 year event for south west Michigan.  The storm also brought blizzard conditions to parts of Kansas, Missouri, Iowa, Illinois, Wisconsin, New York, Vermont, New Hampshire, and Maine.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winter storm conditions began during the late afternoon hours Tuesday, February 1st and continued into the early morning hours on Wednesday. Six to twelve inches of snow fell across the county.  Winds gusts up to 45 mph accompanied one inch per hour snowfall rates.  Snow drifts of 1 to 2 feet occurred in open areas.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions began during the evening hours Tuesday, February 1st and continued into the early morning hours on Wednesday. Eight to seventeen inches of snow were reported across the county. Winds gusts up to 45 mph accompanied 1 to 2 inch hourly snowfall rates.  Snow drifts of 3 to 5 feet occurred in open areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow developed on January 6th and continued over portions of the area through January 8th.  The snow showers were triggered by an Alberta Clipper that tracked north of the area on Jan 6th.  West-northwesterly flow brought widespread snow showers and 2 to 6 inches of snow to most areas west of Route 131 on the 6th into the 7th.  Winds then became more northwest midday on the 7th with heavier snow showers bringing locally a foot of snow to interior Mason County and the southwest corner of Van Buren County.  Local three day snowfall totals exceeded 18 inches. Numerous accidents were reported along US-31 and US-131 on the 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant lake effect snow occurred from the 6th through the 9th, with total snow accumulations reaching approximately 8 inches across western Ottawa county.  A CoCoRaHs observer 4 miles north northeast of Holland reported 8 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A clipper type system advanced toward the Great Lakes region from the west during the afternoon of January 3rd with snow beginning towards evening. Snow with a high water content falling on slightly below freezing road surfaces resulted in very slippery conditions over Western Lower Michigan during the evening hours of the third. A truck jack-knifed during the evening hours on Interstate 96 near Walker.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An NWS employee reported that 4.5 inches of snow fell between 4 p.m. on the third and 7 p.m. on the fourth.  A truck jack-knifed during the evening hours of the third on I-96 near Walker.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A clipper type system advanced toward the Great Lakes region from the west during the afternoon of January 3rd with snow beginning towards evening. A truck jack-knifed during the evening hours on Interstate 96 near Walker.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Muskegon County Airport reported 4.9 inches of snow from the afternoon of the third through 7 p.m. on the fourth.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air spreading over the region resulted in either bitter cold minimum temperatures or periods of wind chill readings to near 25 below zero over the far western interior of Upper Michigan from the 8th through the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The combination of Arctic air and gusty north winds plunged wind chill readings near 25 below zero on the morning of the 8th.  Actual minimum temperatures dipped below zero every morning from the 8th through the 11th reaching extreme readings near 25 below at several locations on the morning of the 11th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air spreading over the region resulted in either bitter cold minimum temperatures or periods of wind chill readings to near 25 below zero over the far western interior of Upper Michigan from the 8th through the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The combination of Arctic air and gusty north winds plunged wind chill readings near 25 below zero on the morning of the 8th.  Actual minimum temperatures dipped below zero every morning from the 8th through the 11th reaching extreme readings near 25 below at several locations on the morning of the 11th. A Caspian man died of exposure to the cold on the 8th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon and evening hours of April 26 as an upper level trough and cold front approached our region.  Several low topped supercells developed and produced numerous reports of large hail up to around two inches in diameter.  In addition a damage survey team from the NWS Grand Rapids office determined that damage caused near Burnips in Allegan County was due to an EF-0 tornado with top winds near 85 mph that damaged buildings at the Deboer Turkey Farm and trailers around the area.  In Portage, nine people were injured by a lightning strike.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dime sized hail occurred on the east side of Holland. Swath was estimated based on correlation of spotter report with maximum estimated hail size, and 0.5 degree reflectivity products form WFO-GRR WSR88D.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through the eastern Great Lakes region produced a 4 to 7 inch snowfall across the thumb region, with generally 1 to 3 inches elsewhere across southeast Michigan. Here are the highest 12 hr snowfall totals reported:|Bad Axe (Huron), 7 inches.|Port Huron (St. Clair), 7 inches.|Lexington (Sanilac), 6 inches.

Lake enhanced snow caused numerous traffic accidents and temporary highway closures across parts of Muskegon, Ottawa and Kent counties including the Grand Rapids metro area.  A new daily snowfall record was set in Muskegon, where 10.7 inches of snow was measured. The heavy snow was localized to Muskegon and Ottawa Counties where snowfall rates exceeded one inch per hour during the morning hours.  Elsewhere three to six inches of snow fell across parts of Allegan, Kent, Oceana, Newaygo, and Mason Counties. The snow occurred in west-southwesterly flow associated with a clipper system that passed by to the north on the 22nd.  Cold temperatures in the teens and wind chills near zero during the event also contributed to the hazardous road conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to 6 inches of snow was reported across northwest Allegan county, with lighter amounts of 2 to 4 inches across eastern Allegan county.

In addition a damage survey team from the NWS Grand Rapids office determined that damage caused near Burnips in Allegan County was due to an EF-0 tornado with top winds near 85 mph that damaged buildings at the Deboer Turkey Farm and trailers around the area.  In Portage, nine people were injured by a lightning strike.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail up to  1.5 inches in diameter fell in a one mile wide swath from Jamestown in extreme northeast Ottawa County through Kentwood and East Grand Rapids. The swath continued northeast towards Belding in northwest Ionia County. The swath was estimated based on the correlation of multiple spotter reports with maximum estimated hail size, NSSL hail swath track algorithm, and 0.5 degree reflectivity products form WFO-GRR WSR88D.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon and evening hours of April 26 as an upper level trough and cold front approached our region.  Several low topped supercells developed and produced numerous reports of large hail up to around two inches in diameter.  In addition a damage survey team from the NWS Grand Rapids office determined that damage caused near Burnips in Allegan County was due to an EF-0 tornado with top winds near 85 mph that damaged buildings at the Deboer Turkey Farm and trailers around the area.  In Portage, nine people were injured by a lightning strike.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported that a severe thunderstorm produced hail up to 1.5 inches in diameter on the northeast side of Belding.  The swath was up to one mile wide and was part of the swath that began in extreme northeast Ottawa County based on correlation with spotter reports and radar hail products.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm impacted southeast Michigan, with snowfall accumulations generally ranging from 6 to 12 inches. Isolated higher amounts were recorded across the Thumb and Tri-Cities Region. Northeast winds gusting between 25 to 35 mph caused some blowing and drifting of snow. Frequent wind gusts to 35 mph came off Lake Huron and Saginaw Bay, leading to blizzard conditions north of the I-69 corridor.||Here are some higher snowfall reports across the area:||Pigeon (Huron), 14 inches.|Port Huron (St. Clair) 14 inches.|Lapeer (Lapeer), 13.6 inches.|Lexington (Sanilac), 13.5 inches.|Bridgeport (Saginaw) 13 inches.|Mayville (Tuscola) 13 inches.|Pinconning (Bay), 12 inches.|Flushing (Genesee), 11 inches.|Lake Orion (Oakland), 10 inches.|Romulus (Wayne), 9 inches.|Dexter (Washtenaw), 8.5 inches.|Ray Center (Macomb), 8.2 inches.|Corunna (Shiawassee) 8 inches.|Tecumseh (Monroe), 7 inches.|Howell (Livingston), 6.2 inches.|Monroe (Monroe), 6 inches.

Lake enhanced snow caused numerous traffic accidents and temporary highway closures across parts of Muskegon, Ottawa and Kent counties including the Grand Rapids metro area.  A new daily snowfall record was set in Muskegon, where 10.7 inches of snow was measured. The heavy snow was localized to Muskegon and Ottawa Counties where snowfall rates exceeded one inch per hour during the morning hours.  Elsewhere three to six inches of snow fell across parts of Allegan, Kent, Oceana, Newaygo, and Mason Counties. The snow occurred in west-southwesterly flow associated with a clipper system that passed by to the north on the 22nd.  Cold temperatures in the teens and wind chills near zero during the event also contributed to the hazardous road conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A NWS employee measured 5.8 inches of snow in extreme western part of the county.  Generally two to four inches fell elsewhere. Numerous accidents were reported in the Grand Rapids area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to four inches of snow fell across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm brought 10 to 15 inches of snow and blizzard conditions to much of southwest lower Michigan the during the late evening of Tuesday, February 1st into the morning hours of Wednesday, February 2nd.  Wind gusts in excess of 40 mph combined with heavy snow to produce whiteout conditions and snowdrifts of 3 to 5 feet.  Thunder accompanied the snow in some areas with snowfall rates exceeding two inches per hour. Many businesses, schools, and some government offices were closed on Wednesday.  Most main roads were plowed by midday Wednesday but some side streets were not cleared until Thursday. The storm is considered a 1 in 10 year event for south west Michigan.  The storm also brought blizzard conditions to parts of Kansas, Missouri, Iowa, Illinois, Wisconsin, New York, Vermont, New Hampshire, and Maine.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions began during the evening hours Tuesday, February 1st and continued into the early morning hours on Wednesday.  Winds gusts up to 50 mph accompanied 1 to 2 inch hourly snowfall rates.  Snow drifts of 3 to 5 feet occurred in open areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm brought heavy wet snow from Holland to Lansing and points north during the afternoon and evening hours of Sunday, February 20th.  South of those areas up to three quarters of an inch of freezing rain.  There were numerous accidents including a sixty car pile-up on Route 131 near Big Rapids.  More than one-hundred thousand people lost power along the Interstate 94 corridor where the freezing rain was the most severe. The storm responsible for the snow and ice was located over eastern South Dakota Sunday morning. The storm center then tracked east moving along the Michigan and Indiana border Sunday night before redeveloping off the Mid-Atlantic Coast on Monday.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ice accumulations of one-quarter to one-half of an inch occurred over the county. The ice was preceded by 2 to 4 inches of a snow-sleet mixture.  Approximately forty-five  thousand people lost power during the storm.  It took up to five days to restore power.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm brought heavy wet snow from Holland to Lansing and points north during the afternoon and evening hours of Sunday, February 20th.  South of those areas up to three quarters of an inch of freezing rain.  There were numerous accidents including a sixty car pile-up on Route 131 near Big Rapids.  More than one-hundred thousand people lost power along the Interstate 94 corridor where the freezing rain was the most severe. The storm center then tracked east moving along the Michigan and Indiana border Sunday night before redeveloping off the Mid-Atlantic Coast on Monday.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ice accumulations of one-tenth to one-quarter of an inch occurred over the county. The ice was preceded by 3 to 6 inches of a snow-sleet mixture.  Approximately ten  thousand people lost power during the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow developed on January 6th and continued over portions of the area through January 8th.  The snow showers were triggered by an Alberta Clipper that tracked north of the area on Jan 6th.  West-northwesterly flow brought widespread snow showers and 2 to 6 inches of snow to most areas west of Route 131 on the 6th into the 7th.  Winds then became more northwest midday on the 7th with heavier snow showers bringing locally a foot of snow to interior Mason County and the southwest corner of Van Buren County.  Local three day snowfall totals exceeded 18 inches. Numerous accidents were reported along US-31 and US-131 on the 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A long duration lake effect snow event occurred from the 6th through the 9th, with total snow accumulations for that time frame ranging from around  a foot and a half across western Lake county to only around 4 to 6 inches over southeast Lake county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A clipper type system advanced toward the Great Lakes region from the west during the afternoon of January 3rd with snow beginning towards evening. Snow with a high water content falling on slightly below freezing road surfaces resulted in very slippery conditions over Western Lower Michigan during the evening hours of the third. A truck jack-knifed during the evening hours on Interstate 96 near Walker.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to four inches of snow was reported across Van Buren county.  A trained spotter in Paw Paw reported 3.5 inches of snow and I-94 near Decatur was briefly closed on the fourth due to multiple crashes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting up from the Plains brought moderate to heavy snow to portions of central and eastern Upper Michigan on the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Menominee measured seven inches of wet snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting up from the Plains brought moderate to heavy snow to portions of central and eastern Upper Michigan on the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer five miles northeast of Garden Corners measured five inches of wet snow in  ten hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers across Delta County reported four to five inches of wet snow in 12 hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers near Iron Mountain measured four inches of wet snow in 12 hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Luce County measured nearly four inches of wet snow in ten hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter near Chatham measured six inches of snow in less than 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved north across southern and central lower Michigan during the day of June 21st, allowing a much warmer and very humid airmass to advect into the area.  Thunderstorms developed during the mid afternoon hours due to the building heat and instability and lake breeze convergence.  The first of the thunderstorms developed near Holland around 4 p.m. just a couple miles inland of Lake Michigan where the convergence was the strongest.  Numerous additional thunderstorms developed in the zone of lake breeze convergence.  The storms eventually congealed into a line of storms which marched eastward across the area during the early to mid evening hours.  ||The storms produced winds of up to around 60 mph in some localized locations.  A gust to near 50 mph at the Gerald R Ford Airport in Grand Rapids produced damage to a couple of hangars that injured four people who were in the hangars at the time.  The storms also produced some hail, with the biggest hail stones measuring over two inches in diameter in Muskegon and just east of Bangor.  ||The most significant issue with the storms however was heavy rainfall.  A storm that produced very heavy rainfall and did not move very fast in eastern Ottawa county from Allendale to near Marne produced 3 to locally 5 inches of rain within a two hour time frame.  This created flooding on parts of the campus of Grand Valley State University, and produced standing water on the roads in Allendale and Tallmadge township in Ottawa county.  Some other areas that received the highest rainfall totals were near the intersection of Isabella, Montcalm and Gratiot counties.  Western Calhoun county also received significant rainfall and portions of the aforementioned areas saw up to 5 inches of rain falling in a 2 to 3 hour time frame.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: B Drive South between 4 Mile Road and 4 1/2 Mile Road flooded to a depth of 4.5 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the evening hours, thunderstorms began to initiate in a moderate to strongly unstable environment along a southwest to northeast oriented surface cold front located in Wisconsin and extending into the Upper Peninsula of Michigan.  The storms quickly grew upscale into a linear MCS and raced to the east toward Lake Michigan. The convective system began to come ashore in lower Michigan during the late evening hours. The storms from Muskegon County to the north maintained their strength and produced numerous reports of widespread tree damage and a few reports of large hail, though storms along the line southward from Muskegon County weakened significantly as they approached the Michigan shores. However, widespread wind damage was still observed with a very strong gust front that advanced quickly ahead of the leading line of convection. The gust front produced winds of 50 to over 60 miles per hour and numerous reports of downed trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: As a strong gust front swept across the county, numerous trees and branches were reported down countywide by both law enforcement and trained spotters. Some roads were blocked by fallen trees and had to be cleared by the county Road Commission. Additionally, some scattered power outages were observed.

Numerous additional thunderstorms developed in the zone of lake breeze convergence.  The storms eventually congealed into a line of storms which marched eastward across the area during the early to mid evening hours.  ||The storms produced winds of up to around 60 mph in some localized locations.  A gust to near 50 mph at the Gerald R Ford Airport in Grand Rapids produced damage to a couple of hangars that injured four people who were in the hangars at the time.  The storms also produced some hail, with the biggest hail stones measuring over two inches in diameter in Muskegon and just east of Bangor.  ||The most significant issue with the storms however was heavy rainfall.  A storm that produced very heavy rainfall and did not move very fast in eastern Ottawa county from Allendale to near Marne produced 3 to locally 5 inches of rain within a two hour time frame.  This created flooding on parts of the campus of Grand Valley State University, and produced standing water on the roads in Allendale and Tallmadge township in Ottawa county.  Some other areas that received the highest rainfall totals were near the intersection of Isabella, Montcalm and Gratiot counties.  Western Calhoun county also received significant rainfall and portions of the aforementioned areas saw up to 5 inches of rain falling in a 2 to 3 hour time frame.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported an estimated severe thunderstorm wind gust to 70 mph at Twin Lake.  Numerous tree branches were blown down and there was also damage to a pontoon boat and garage roof.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved north across southern and central lower Michigan during the day of June 21st, allowing a much warmer and very humid airmass to advect into the area.  Thunderstorms developed during the mid afternoon hours due to the building heat and instability and lake breeze convergence.  The first of the thunderstorms developed near Holland around 4 p.m. just a couple miles inland of Lake Michigan where the convergence was the strongest.  Numerous additional thunderstorms developed in the zone of lake breeze convergence.  The storms eventually congealed into a line of storms which marched eastward across the area during the early to mid evening hours.  ||The storms produced winds of up to around 60 mph in some localized locations.  A gust to near 50 mph at the Gerald R Ford Airport in Grand Rapids produced damage to a couple of hangars that injured four people who were in the hangars at the time.  The storms also produced some hail, with the biggest hail stones measuring over two inches in diameter in Muskegon and just east of Bangor.  ||The most significant issue with the storms however was heavy rainfall.  A storm that produced very heavy rainfall and did not move very fast in eastern Ottawa county from Allendale to near Marne produced 3 to locally 5 inches of rain within a two hour time frame.  This created flooding on parts of the campus of Grand Valley State University, and produced standing water on the roads in Allendale and Tallmadge township in Ottawa county.  Some other areas that received the highest rainfall totals were near the intersection of Isabella, Montcalm and Gratiot counties.  Western Calhoun county also received significant rainfall and portions of the aforementioned areas saw up to 5 inches of rain falling in a 2 to 3 hour time frame.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One and a quarters inch hail was reported by a trained spotter near Grand Haven.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the evening hours, thunderstorms began to initiate in a moderate to strongly unstable environment along a southwest to northeast oriented surface cold front located in Wisconsin and extending into the Upper Peninsula of Michigan.  The storms quickly grew upscale into a linear MCS and raced to the east toward Lake Michigan. The convective system began to come ashore in lower Michigan during the late evening hours. The storms from Muskegon County to the north maintained their strength and produced numerous reports of widespread tree damage and a few reports of large hail, though storms along the line southward from Muskegon County weakened significantly as they approached the Michigan shores. However, widespread wind damage was still observed with a very strong gust front that advanced quickly ahead of the leading line of convection. The gust front produced winds of 50 to over 60 miles per hour and numerous reports of downed trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A report of large hail of 1.5 inches was reported in northern Mecosta County along with a measure wind gust of 43 miles per hour by a trained spotter. Additionally, trees and power lines were reported to be down countywide by the Mecosta County Road Commission, particularly near the Big Rapids area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm complex rolled through southeast Michigan during the peak heating of the day, resulting in scattered wind damage reports across the area. Embedded circulations within the line of thunderstorms lead to localized wind gusts to 80 mph, with even one confirmed tornado over southern Shiawassee county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous 6 to 8 inch diameter trees limbs reported down.

Two homes on the lake had trees that had fallen upon them.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of showers and thunderstorms impacted Northern Michigan for much of the day on the 11th.  The storms produced isolated severe weather and excessive rainfall, along with an area of high winds associated with a wake low trailing well behind the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wake low, trailing well behind a large area of thunderstorms, producing damaging winds near Sault Ste Marie.  A gust of 55 mph was measured at Sanderson Field in the Sault.  Over two dozen trees were downed along South Mackinac Trail, and scattered trees were downed elsewhere in the area.  A tree fell onto a home in the Sault.  Several roofs had shingles removed, and two billboards along I-75 sustained heavy damage.  A garage and barn were damaged a few miles southeast of the Sault.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of showers and thunderstorms impacted Northern Michigan for much of the day on the 11th.  The storms produced isolated severe weather and excessive rainfall, along with an area of high winds associated with a wake low trailing well behind the storms.

During the evening hours, thunderstorms began to initiate in a moderate to strongly unstable environment along a southwest to northeast oriented surface cold front located in Wisconsin and extending into the Upper Peninsula of Michigan.  The storms quickly grew upscale into a linear MCS and raced to the east toward Lake Michigan. The convective system began to come ashore in lower Michigan during the late evening hours. The storms from Muskegon County to the north maintained their strength and produced numerous reports of widespread tree damage and a few reports of large hail, though storms along the line southward from Muskegon County weakened significantly as they approached the Michigan shores. However, widespread wind damage was still observed with a very strong gust front that advanced quickly ahead of the leading line of convection. The gust front produced winds of 50 to over 60 miles per hour and numerous reports of downed trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A gust front surged well ahead of a weakening line of convection, and as it swept through Calhoun county, a trained spotter measured a 66 mph wind gust on a hand held anemometer at 24th street and Territorial. Additionally, the ASOS weather station located 1 mile NW of Battle Creek measured a wind gust of 51 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Training thunderstorms brought excessive rainfall to the Wellston area.  A cooperative observer, 1 mile north of Wellston, measured 5.05 inches of rain from 9 am to 9 pm.  A considerable amount of standing water developed on area roads, and some were closed for part of the afternoon.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a home, igniting a small roof fire that was brought under control within an hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of showers and thunderstorms impacted Northern Michigan for much of the day on the 11th.  The storms produced isolated severe weather and excessive rainfall, along with an area of high winds associated with a wake low trailing well behind the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Persistent thunderstorms produced periodic, significant street flooding in and near the city of Manistee.  A spotter in Manistee measured 4.44 inches of rain from 9 am to 9 pm.  Water rose over the curbs of many city streets, and parts of US-31 and M-22 were closed for part of the afternoon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface trough dropping south through Saginaw Bay interacted with thunderstorms coming up from the south, producing heavy rainfall around the I-69 corridor, specifically in Genessee county where flash flooding occured.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Estimated rainfall of at least 2 to 4 inches caused water over roads and flooded properties.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved north across southern and central lower Michigan during the day of June 21st, allowing a much warmer and very humid airmass to advect into the area.  Thunderstorms developed during the mid afternoon hours due to the building heat and instability and lake breeze convergence.  The first of the thunderstorms developed near Holland around 4 p.m. just a couple miles inland of Lake Michigan where the convergence was the strongest.  Numerous additional thunderstorms developed in the zone of lake breeze convergence.  The storms eventually congealed into a line of storms which marched eastward across the area during the early to mid evening hours.  ||The storms produced winds of up to around 60 mph in some localized locations.  A gust to near 50 mph at the Gerald R Ford Airport in Grand Rapids produced damage to a couple of hangars that injured four people who were in the hangars at the time.  The storms also produced some hail, with the biggest hail stones measuring over two inches in diameter in Muskegon and just east of Bangor.  ||The most significant issue with the storms however was heavy rainfall.  A storm that produced very heavy rainfall and did not move very fast in eastern Ottawa county from Allendale to near Marne produced 3 to locally 5 inches of rain within a two hour time frame.  This created flooding on parts of the campus of Grand Valley State University, and produced standing water on the roads in Allendale and Tallmadge township in Ottawa county.  Some other areas that received the highest rainfall totals were near the intersection of Isabella, Montcalm and Gratiot counties.  Western Calhoun county also received significant rainfall and portions of the aforementioned areas saw up to 5 inches of rain falling in a 2 to 3 hour time frame.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Radar estimated that large hail fell from just southeast of Hartford to the north northeast across east central Van Buren county to north of Bloomingdale.  A report of two inch diameter hail was received just east of Bangor.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm complex rolled through southeast Michigan during the peak heating of the day, resulting in scattered wind damage reports across the area. Embedded circulations within the line of thunderstorms lead to localized wind gusts to 80 mph, with even one confirmed tornado over southern Shiawassee county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees reported blown down along with a power line.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado which originated in Ingham county crossed into Shiawassee county near LoveJoy and Locke Roads at 528 PM, tracking northeast for around three miles, ending at Beard and Ruppert Roads at 532 pm. The damage path was about 100 yards wide. Damage was mostly soft and hard wood trees uprooted and snapped, with estimated max wind speed of 90 mph, making this Tornado an EF1.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front worked north into portions of far southern lower Michigan during the late morning hours. A line of severe thunderstorms developed in eastern Iowa and moved rapidly east into Indiana. Initially the storms were sub severe as they moved across Lake Michigan but quickly organized and became severe as they entered St. Joseph county. An area of wind damage occurred across St. Joseph county with a brief tornado touched down in Coldwater in Branch county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A survey of damage indicated the start of a roughly one mile wide swath of wind damage that started in northeastern Cass county and continued into St. Joseph county. The swath of wind occurred mainly across a heavily wooded portion of the county, resulting in hundreds of trees being snapped or uprooted. In addition, power poles and lines in the area suffered extensive damage. Wind speeds were estimated to be in the 90 to 100 mph range based on the degree of damage and radar evidence.

Embedded circulations within the line of thunderstorms lead to localized wind gusts to 80 mph, with even one confirmed tornado over southern Shiawassee county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two large trees were blown down. One tree fell onto a back deck and hot tub and extended into a garage. The other tree destroyed a driveway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm drifted south and became severe as it moved into Jenison and Grandville, producing a couple of one inch hail reports.  Numerous other thunderstorms that drifted from north to south through the day contained heavy rainfall but the vast majority of hail reports ranged from pea sized to half inch in diameter.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter estimated hail size of one inch in diameter at 44th and Kenowa.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts caused two civilian hangars to become damaged and collapse at the Gerald R. Ford International Airport, causing four injuries. The damage occurred at the north end of the airport and affected a row of general aviation hangers.  The injuries occurred due to debris from the two hangars that collapsed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system from the Northern Plains brought moderate snow to much of western Upper Michigan on the 3rd and 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer northeast of Calumet measured a storm total snowfall of nearly seven inches. Periods of freezing drizzle were also reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into northwest Ontario helped spawn thunderstorms with dime to penny-sized hail on the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dime-sized hail fell at an apartment.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into northwest Ontario helped spawn thunderstorms with dime to penny-sized hail on the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer also reported heavy rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A marginal severe thunderstorm moved through northern Huron county.
A marginal severe thunderstorm moved through northern Huron county.
A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into northwest Ontario helped spawn thunderstorms with dime to penny-sized hail on the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pea and penny-sized hail were also observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another low pressure system moving in from Wisconsin brought moderate snow to Gogebic County from the 26th into the 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Ironwood measured six inches of wet snow in less than 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the mid to late afternoon hours of May 29 from Vicksburg east northeast to Battle Creek and Charlotte.  An NWS storm survey found significant damage resulting from straight line wind damage resulting from severe thunderstorm winds of up to 85 to 100 mph.  A state of emergency was declared for Calhoun county due to widespread wind damage.||The storms developed north of a warm front that separated mild weather to the north of it from hot weather south of the boundary.  The storms traveled into northern Illinois just after noon, and then moved across southern lower Michigan between 2 pm and 6 pm. The storms strengthened as they reached far southern lower Michigan as they encountered warmer and more humid air.  The NWS Grand Rapids storm survey teams found no conclusive evidence of any tornadoes from southern Kalamazoo county east northeast through Calhoun county and up into Eaton and Ingham counties.  Nearly 40,000 people across Calhoun county lost power due to all the wind damage and lightning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The bowing segment of a line echo wave pattern caused extensive damage to homes, businesses, and utilities on the south side of Battle Creek along E Columbia Ave. Approximately 600 homes were damaged with 76 of those homes having been destroyed. Also, 21 businesses were damaged of which 4 were destroyed. To the north and east of the Battle Creek area, two dozen rural properties also sustained damage. Throughout the county, over 40,000 customers were without power and thousands of trees were either uprooted or snapped. The damage path was 33 miles long and ranged from 0.5 mile up to 2 miles in width.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the mid to late afternoon hours of May 29 from Vicksburg east northeast to Battle Creek and Charlotte.  An NWS storm survey found significant damage resulting from straight line wind damage resulting from severe thunderstorm winds of up to 85 to 100 mph.  A state of emergency was declared for Calhoun county due to widespread wind damage.||The storms developed north of a warm front that separated mild weather to the north of it from hot weather south of the boundary.  The storms traveled into northern Illinois just after noon, and then moved across southern lower Michigan between 2 pm and 6 pm. The storms strengthened as they reached far southern lower Michigan as they encountered warmer and more humid air.  The NWS Grand Rapids storm survey teams found no conclusive evidence of any tornadoes from southern Kalamazoo county east northeast through Calhoun county and up into Eaton and Ingham counties.  Nearly 40,000 people across Calhoun county lost power due to all the wind damage and lightning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A damage path of nearly 20 miles in length and 0.5-1 mile in width was caused by a bowing segment of an MCS. The path extended from Onondaga northeast to Vantown. As a result of the high winds, numerous large trees were wither uprooted or snapped. Some homes sustained roof damage as well as some barns.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the mid to late afternoon hours of May 29 from Vicksburg east northeast to Battle Creek and Charlotte.  An NWS storm survey found significant damage resulting from straight line wind damage resulting from severe thunderstorm winds of up to 85 to 100 mph.  A state of emergency was declared for Calhoun county due to widespread wind damage.||The storms developed north of a warm front that separated mild weather to the north of it from hot weather south of the boundary.  The storms traveled into northern Illinois just after noon, and then moved across southern lower Michigan between 2 pm and 6 pm. The storms strengthened as they reached far southern lower Michigan as they encountered warmer and more humid air.  The NWS Grand Rapids storm survey teams found no conclusive evidence of any tornadoes from southern Kalamazoo county east northeast through Calhoun county and up into Eaton and Ingham counties.  Nearly 40,000 people across Calhoun county lost power due to all the wind damage and lightning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The areas most impacted by the bowing segment of the line echo wave pattern fell within Brady and Wakeshma Townships along and south of E W Avenue between 33rd and 47th Streets. Hundreds of trees were either uprooted or snapped, with some snapped 15-20 feet above the ground. Additionally, some structures were damaged with this storm. A grain silo on the corner of E W Avenue and S 40th Street collapsed, and nearly a dozen farm buildings sustained significant roof damage. The damage path was approximately 8 miles long and 3 miles wide.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the mid to late afternoon hours of May 29 from Vicksburg east northeast to Battle Creek and Charlotte.  An NWS storm survey found significant damage resulting from straight line wind damage resulting from severe thunderstorm winds of up to 85 to 100 mph.  A state of emergency was declared for Calhoun county due to widespread wind damage.||The storms developed north of a warm front that separated mild weather to the north of it from hot weather south of the boundary.  The storms traveled into northern Illinois just after noon, and then moved across southern lower Michigan between 2 pm and 6 pm. The storms strengthened as they reached far southern lower Michigan as they encountered warmer and more humid air.  The NWS Grand Rapids storm survey teams found no conclusive evidence of any tornadoes from southern Kalamazoo county east northeast through Calhoun county and up into Eaton and Ingham counties.  Nearly 40,000 people across Calhoun county lost power due to all the wind damage and lightning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small tornado touched down in extreme northern Ingham county before crossing over into Shiawassee county. Trees were snapped in a 100 yard wide area, and both a residence and a barn had their roofs partially blown off.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the mid to late afternoon hours of May 29 from Vicksburg east northeast to Battle Creek and Charlotte.  An NWS storm survey found significant damage resulting from straight line wind damage resulting from severe thunderstorm winds of up to 85 to 100 mph.  A state of emergency was declared for Calhoun county due to widespread wind damage.||The storms developed north of a warm front that separated mild weather to the north of it from hot weather south of the boundary.  The storms traveled into northern Illinois just after noon, and then moved across southern lower Michigan between 2 pm and 6 pm. The storms strengthened as they reached far southern lower Michigan as they encountered warmer and more humid air.  The NWS Grand Rapids storm survey teams found no conclusive evidence of any tornadoes from southern Kalamazoo county east northeast through Calhoun county and up into Eaton and Ingham counties.  Nearly 40,000 people across Calhoun county lost power due to all the wind damage and lightning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A swath of damage approximately 12 miles long and 0.5 to 1 mile in width occurred SE of Charlotte to just NNE of Eaton Rapids. The damage resulted from a bowing segment of a line echo wave pattern which downed numerous trees and power lines. Several homes in the area sustained roof damage, and one home approximately 3 mi NW of Eaton Rapids was partially destroyed. However, that home was not properly attached to its foundation. Several barns were also damaged, one of which was destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the mid to late afternoon hours of May 29 from Vicksburg east northeast to Battle Creek and Charlotte.  An NWS storm survey found significant damage resulting from straight line wind damage resulting from severe thunderstorm winds of up to 85 to 100 mph.  A state of emergency was declared for Calhoun county due to widespread wind damage.||The storms developed north of a warm front that separated mild weather to the north of it from hot weather south of the boundary.  The storms traveled into northern Illinois just after noon, and then moved across southern lower Michigan between 2 pm and 6 pm. The storms strengthened as they reached far southern lower Michigan as they encountered warmer and more humid air.  The NWS Grand Rapids storm survey teams found no conclusive evidence of any tornadoes from southern Kalamazoo county east northeast through Calhoun county and up into Eaton and Ingham counties.  Nearly 40,000 people across Calhoun county lost power due to all the wind damage and lightning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The bow echo impacted mainly rural areas of Brookfield and Hamlin Townships. The damage path, which was 8 miles long and up to 1 mile in width, was an extension of the damage path seen in Calhoun county.  Hundreds of trees were either uprooted or snapped, and a half of a dozen farms received property damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An MCS moved into the southern portions of the county warning area during the evening hours. As the system move east northeast through southern lower Michigan, scattered wind damage was reported in Van Buren, Kalamazoo, Calhoun, and Ingham counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 58 mph wind gust was measured by the Kalamazoo ASOS. Trained spotters also reported tree branches down in between the I-94 corridor and downtown Kalamazoo.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms developed east of the US-131 corridor during the late afternoon hours of May 31st in an axis of strong instability in advance of an approaching cold front.  Hail up to an inch and a half in diameter was reported three to four miles east of Mount Pleasant.  A trained spotter in Winn in southern Isabella county also reported 65 to 75 mph wind gusts in conjunction with one inch hail with that severe storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A supercell thunderstorm tracked from west southwest to east northeast across southern Isabella county, producing several reports of large hail up to an inch and a half in diameter three to four miles east of Mt. Pleasant.  A trained spotter in Winn estimated the storm produced wind gusts of 65 to 75 mph along with one inch diameter hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An MCS moved into the southern portions of the county warning area during the evening hours. As the system move east northeast through southern lower Michigan, scattered wind damage was reported in Van Buren, Kalamazoo, Calhoun, and Ingham counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Calhoun county emergency manager reported multiple large, healthy trees down within Emmett Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An MCS moved into the southern portions of the county warning area during the evening hours. As the system move east northeast through southern lower Michigan, scattered wind damage was reported in Van Buren, Kalamazoo, Calhoun, and Ingham counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A county official reported that multiple trees were uprooted near the intersection of E Kalamazoo Street and Shepard Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong late afternoon thunderstorm affected portions of southeastern Jackson county, resulting in three quarters inch diameter hail in Napoleon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter in Napoleon reported three quarters inch diameter hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracking eastward through the Lower Great Lakes brought significant heavy wet snow to south central Upper Michigan.  With a strong high pressure system centered over Ontario providing very dry air across Lake Superior and northern Upper Michigan, there was a very sharp snowfall gradient between the heavy snow and no snow at all.  The pressure difference across the area also resulted in gusty east winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate wet snow fell mainly along and south of US 2. A weather spotter reported 4 inches of heavy wet snow 6 miles southwest of Ford River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms developed east of the US-131 corridor during the late afternoon hours of May 31st in an axis of strong instability in advance of an approaching cold front.  Hail up to an inch and a half in diameter was reported three to four miles east of Mount Pleasant.  A trained spotter in Winn in southern Isabella county also reported 65 to 75 mph wind gusts in conjunction with one inch hail with that severe storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported that one inch hail fell in northern Gratiot county near the intersection of Jefferson and Begole roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking northeast into the Eastern Great Lakes allowed rain to change to snow, with total accumulations of 4 to 8 inches occuring over the Tri-Cities region, Shiawassee, and Livingston counties. Elsewhere, generally 1 to 4 inches of wet snow fell. Here are some of the higher snowfall accumulations reported to the National Weather Service:|Auburn (Bay) 8 inches.|Perry (Shiawassee) 8 inches.|Midland (Midland) 6.6 inches.|Howell (Livingston) 6.2 inches.|Bridgeport (Saginaw) 6.1 inches.
A low pressure system moving through the Upper Great Lakes dumped a swath of heavy snow over much of west and north central Upper Michigan mainly in the afternoon and evening of the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Winona measured eight inches of wet heavy snow in a 12-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving through the Upper Great Lakes dumped a swath of heavy snow over much of west and north central Upper Michigan mainly in the afternoon and evening of the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A swath of ten inches of wet heavy snow fell from White Pine to Rockland in an eight-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow developed on January 6th and continued over portions of the area through January 8th.  The snow showers were triggered by an Alberta Clipper that tracked north of the area on Jan 6th.  West-northwesterly flow brought widespread snow showers and 2 to 6 inches of snow to most areas west of Route 131 on the 6th into the 7th.  Winds then became more northwest midday on the 7th with heavier snow showers bringing locally a foot of snow to interior Mason County and the southwest corner of Van Buren County.  Local three day snowfall totals exceeded 18 inches. Numerous accidents were reported along US-31 and US-131 on the 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A CoCoRaHs observer four miles south southwest of Hastings measured 7 inches of snow from the 6th through 6 p.m. on the 8th.  Several rounds of lake effect snow impacted Barry county from the 6th through the 9th, with total snow accumulations ranging from four to seven inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slippery roads from several inches of lake effect snow contributed to numerous car accidents across Gogebic County on the 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Slippery roads from several inches of lake effect snow contributed to numerous car   accidents from Ironwood through Wakefield to Marenisco on the 16th.  One two-car accident in Bessemer resulted in injuries to a 44 year-old man.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow developed on January 6th and continued over portions of the area through January 8th.  The snow showers were triggered by an Alberta Clipper that tracked north of the area on Jan 6th.  West-northwesterly flow brought widespread snow showers and 2 to 6 inches of snow to most areas west of Route 131 on the 6th into the 7th.  Winds then became more northwest midday on the 7th with heavier snow showers bringing locally a foot of snow to interior Mason County and the southwest corner of Van Buren County.  Local three day snowfall totals exceeded 18 inches. Numerous accidents were reported along US-31 and US-131 on the 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to twelve inches of snow fell across portions of southwestern Van Buren county.  The heaviest snow, with rates of one to two inches per hour, fell during the morning hours of the January 8th.  Three to six inches of snow fell in the northern and eastern parts of the county. The snow was light with an estimated snow-ratio of 20 to 1.  Some blowing and drifting occurred with occasional wind gusts exceeding 25 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of clipper low pressure systems moving through the region helped generate moderate to heavy lake effect snow showers downwind of Lake Superior in a northwest to north flow from the 6th into the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Calumet measured 11 inches of snow in 12-hour period ending on the morning of the 8th and also reported one-quarter mile visibility in heavy snow and blowing snow.  One-inch per hour snowfall rates were reported in the Houghton/Hancock area from the evening of the 7th into the early morning of the 8th with a lot of blowing and drifting of snow. The observer at Twin Lakes also measured 12.5 inches in the 24-hour period ending on the morning of the 8th with a four-day storm total snowfall of 31 inches ending on the morning of the 9th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Locally six to nine inches of snow fell along coastal sections of Allegan and Ottawa Counties Thursday afternoon.  The heaviest amounts were in the Holland area.  The snow was light with snow-ratios greater than 20 to 1.  The snow was associated with a single lake effect snow band that formed in westerly flow ahead of a weak wave of low pressure that passed north of the area Thursday evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to nine inches of snow was reported in the Holland area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Locally six to nine inches of snow fell along coastal sections of Allegan and Ottawa Counties Thursday afternoon.  The heaviest amounts were in the Holland area.  The snow was light with snow-ratios greater than 20 to 1.  The snow was associated with a single lake effect snow band that formed in westerly flow ahead of a weak wave of low pressure that passed north of the area Thursday evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Locally six to nine inches of snow was reported in southwest and western Ottawa county, including a report of nine inches of snow in Grand Haven.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into eastern Upper Michigan brought moderate to heavy snow and blowing snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 14th through the 15th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter near Wakefield reported six inches of snow in the 12-hour period ending on the evening of the 15th.

Increasing northwesterly flow behind a departing storm system set the stage for an intense lake effect snow band over Berrien County on January 12th. Snowfall amounts ranged from near 8 inches in far southwest Berrien County to 3-6 inches elsewhere.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An intense lake effect snow band set up over the area during the early morning hours of January 12, and continued through much of day.  Snowfall rates around an inch per hour were common within this band, with Millburg reporting 7 inches of snow accumulation and Benton Harbor 4.5 inches of snow. This event created hazardous driving conditions with accidents and slide-offs reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak low pressure at the surface and aloft helped spin up a weak tornado in the Helmer Bay portion of Manistique Lake in southern Luce County on the evening of the 23rd.  After formation the weak tornado then moved south toward Curtis in Mackinac County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Weak low pressure and cold air aloft helped spin up a weak tornado/waterspout in the Helmer Bay portion of Manistique Lake during the early evening of the 23rd.  The tornado/waterspout was not associated with a thunderstorm.  The tornado touched down 4.57 miles south southwest of McMillan Corner and moved southward crossing into the Mackinac County portion of Big Manistique Lake 5.88 miles south southwest of McMillan Corner. The tornado then continued southward an additional mile into Mackinac County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Plains produced areas of moderate snow on the 17th and 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated four to five inches of snow fell between Garden Corners and Manistique in a 12-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Plains produced areas of moderate snow on the 17th and 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers near South Range and Twin Lakes measured nearly seven inches of snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several intense lake effect snow bands set up across Berrien and western Cass counties on January 7th and 8th.  The heaviest snows, with snowfall rates in excess of 4 inches per hour, were experienced late January 7th into the morning hours of January 8th. Snowfall totals between 1 and 2 feet were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow bands developed during the day on January 7th and transitioned into an intense single band late on January 7th into much of the morning hours of January 8th.  Snowfall rates of greater than 4 inches per hour were reported within this single band, with total snowfall amounts generally ranging between 1 and 2 feet.  A trained spotter in Benton Harbor reported 19 inches of total snow accumulation.  Rapidly accumulating snow combined with visibilities less than a quarter of a mile created hazardous driving conditions across the county, resulting in accidents and slide-offs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several intense lake effect snow bands set up across Berrien and western Cass counties on January 7th and 8th.  The heaviest snows, with snowfall rates in excess of 4 inches per hour, were experienced late January 7th into the morning hours of January 8th. Snowfall totals between 1 and 2 feet were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow bands developed across mainly western portions of the county during the day on January 7th, and transitioned into an intense single band late on January 7th into much of the morning hours of January 8th.  Snowfall rates of greater than 4 inches per hour were reported within this single band, with total snowfall amounts generally ranging between 1 and 2 feet in western Cass County.  A CoCoRaHS observer in Dowagiac reported over 14 inches of total snow snow accumulation.  Rapidly accumulating snow combined with visibilities less than a quarter of a mile created hazardous driving conditions across the county, resulting in accidents and slide-offs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening low pressure system lifting northeast of Upper Michigan into Ontario caused damaging winds across much of Upper Michigan near Lake Superior from the 14th into the early morning of the 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several healthy pine trees were knocked down near Merriweather along Highway M-28.  Exact size of the trees was unknown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening low pressure system lifting northeast of Upper Michigan into Ontario caused damaging winds across much of Upper Michigan near Lake Superior from the 14th into the early morning of the 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Lac La Belle Fire Department reported an 18-inch diameter tree down across the road at the fire station.  Several trees were down on power lines near Eagle Harbor.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening low pressure system lifting northeast of Upper Michigan into Ontario caused damaging winds across much of Upper Michigan near Lake Superior from the 14th into the early morning of the 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were reported down near Laurium including two 24-inch diameter trees next to the Calumet High School.  Time of the event was estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening low pressure system lifting northeast of Upper Michigan into Ontario caused damaging winds across much of Upper Michigan near Lake Superior from the 14th into the early morning of the 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Luce County Sheriff reported numerous trees down across the county resulting in several power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow showers and blowing snow in the wake of an Arctic cold front mainly affected portions of the Keweenaw Peninsula and areas east of Munising along the Lake Superior shoreline from the 8th into the morning of the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Toivola estimated 12 inches of lake effect snow fell in a 12-hour period ending on the morning of the 9th.  A public report from Twin Lakes measured 10 to 11 inches of snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow showers and blowing snow in the wake of an Arctic cold front mainly affected portions of the Keweenaw Peninsula and areas east of Munising along the Lake Superior shoreline from the 8th into the morning of the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers in Grand Marais measured nine to ten inches of lake effect snow in a 6-hour period.  Near blizzard conditions in blowing snow were also reported as west winds gusted to around 35 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow showers and blowing snow in the wake of an Arctic cold front mainly affected portions of the Keweenaw Peninsula and areas east of Munising along the Lake Superior shoreline from the 8th into the morning of the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A public report from the town of Gay estimated 7 to 8 inches of lake effect snow over a 12-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow showers and blowing snow in the wake of an Arctic cold front mainly affected portions of the Keweenaw Peninsula and areas east of Munising along the Lake Superior shoreline from the 8th into the morning of the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Slippery roadways caused by an inch of lake effect snow moving through the area resulted in at least four accidents around the Marquette area on the morning of the 8th.  Three of the accidents occurred along Highway M-553, the most serious of which occurred just south of Marquette Mountain at around 7 am.  This two-car crash resulted in injuries to the driver and two passengers of the northbound vehicle which lost control and collided with the southbound vehicle.  All three people were transported to Marquette General Hospital.  A fourth accident occurred near Shiras Hills in Marquette.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slushy mixture of rain and snow contributed to a fatal accident on US Highway 45 near Bruce Crossing at 11 am on the morning of the 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A slushy mixture of rain and snow contributed to a fatal accident on US Highway 45 near Bruce Crossing at 11 am on the morning of the 14th.  Michigan State Police in Wakefield reported that a 36 year-old Michigan Tech University student from St. Paul, MN was killed when the vehicle he was driving spun head-on into the path of a semi-tractor and trailer rig driven by a Greenland man.  The Greenland man received minor injuries in the accident according to police reports.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening low pressure system lifting northeast of Upper Michigan into Ontario caused damaging winds across much of Upper Michigan near Lake Superior from the 14th into the early morning of the 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts measured at the Grand Marais GLOS site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening low pressure system lifting northeast of Upper Michigan into Ontario caused damaging winds across much of Upper Michigan near Lake Superior from the 14th into the early morning of the 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ten-inch diameter maple tree snapped in half near Silver City.  No leaves were on the tree.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening low pressure system lifting northeast of Upper Michigan into Ontario caused damaging winds across much of Upper Michigan near Lake Superior from the 14th into the early morning of the 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gust measured by the GLOS site in Grand Marais.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening low pressure system lifting northeast of Upper Michigan into Ontario caused damaging winds across much of Upper Michigan near Lake Superior from the 14th into the early morning of the 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Keweenaw County Sheriff reported several trees down due to high winds overnight...including near Eagle River, across Highway US-41 near Lake Medora and Five-Mile Road near Allouez.  Time of the event was estimated from the Portage Lake GLOS site and the Houghton County Airport ASOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening low pressure system lifting northeast of Upper Michigan into Ontario caused damaging winds across much of Upper Michigan near Lake Superior from the 14th into the early morning of the 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The State Police Post reported trees down across the county overnight, including trees on power lines. Time of the report was estimated based on wind gusts at the Portage Canal GLOS and the Houghton County Airport ASOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow developed on January 6th and continued over portions of the area through January 8th.  The snow showers were triggered by an Alberta Clipper that tracked north of the area on Jan 6th.  West-northwesterly flow brought widespread snow showers and 2 to 6 inches of snow to most areas west of Route 131 on the 6th into the 7th.  Winds then became more northwest midday on the 7th with heavier snow showers bringing locally a foot of snow to interior Mason County and the southwest corner of Van Buren County.  Local three day snowfall totals exceeded 18 inches. Numerous accidents were reported along US-31 and US-131 on the 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to twelve inches of snow fell along and west of Route 31. Snowfall rates of 2 inches per hour occurred at times during the event.  The snow was light with an estimated snow-ratio of 20 to 1.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow developed on January 6th and continued over portions of the area through January 8th. Local three day snowfall totals exceeded 18 inches. Numerous accidents were reported along US-31 and US-131 on the 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A long duration lake effect snow event occurred from the 6th through the 9th, with total snow accumulations for that time frame reaching 10 to 12 inches across western Oceana county.  CoCoRaHs observers near Stony Lake and Walkerville both reported 10 to 12 inches of snow, with the heaviest snow occurring on the 7th into the early morning hours of the 8th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow developed on January 6th and continued over portions of the area through January 8th.  The snow showers were triggered by an Alberta Clipper that tracked north of the area on Jan 6th.  West-northwesterly flow brought widespread snow showers and 2 to 6 inches of snow to most areas west of Route 131 on the 6th into the 7th.  Winds then became more northwest midday on the 7th with heavier snow showers bringing locally a foot of snow to interior Mason County and the southwest corner of Van Buren County.  Local three day snowfall totals exceeded 18 inches. Numerous accidents were reported along US-31 and US-131 on the 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of lake effect snow impacted Allegan county from the 6th through the 9th, with total snow accumulations reaching around ten to twelve inches across far west southwest Allegan county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid day with heat indices around 100 degrees ended with numerous severe thunderstorms across southeast Michigan as a cold front moved through the region.

An isolated severe thunderstorm produced wind damage in Big Rapids, where emergency management reported that 15 trees were snapped off or blown down.  Flooding also occurred in Big Rapids.  The Robin Hood airport in Big Rapids received 5.97 inches of rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mecosta county emergency management reported that 15 trees were snapped off or blown down in the city of Big Rapids.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid day with heat indices around 100 degrees ended with numerous severe thunderstorms across southeast Michigan as a cold front moved through the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and tree limbs reported down across the  northern part of Grosse Ile.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and tree limbs reported down across the south part of Grosse Ile.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid day with heat indices around 100 degrees ended with numerous severe thunderstorms across southeast Michigan as a cold front moved through the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to four inch diameter tree limbs reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure was located over northwestern Iowa with a warm front well north into Michigan. The main upper level jet energy remained west of the area. The environment consisted of strong instability, with surface based CAPE in excess of 500 j/kg and low shear. Storms struggled initially with isolated reports of hail or wind damage. As the storms congealed, larger segments of storms took shape, causing more widespread wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was blown down across Adolph Road near Clay Road, just south of Union City.

The environment consisted of strong instability, with surface based CAPE in excess of 500 j/kg and low shear. Storms struggled initially with isolated reports of hail or wind damage. As the storms congealed, larger segments of storms took shape, causing more widespread wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement officials reported trees and power lines down at various locations throughout the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving through a warm and unstable airmass triggered a line of severe thunderstorms which affected portions of the Keweenaw Peninsula on the evening of the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Calumet Golf Club sustained tree damage.  Several oak trees approximately one-foot in diameter were snapped.  Several pine tree branches six inches in diameter were broken off.  A one-foot diameter pine tree was also uprooted.  Trees all fell to the northeast.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms lifted northward, along a warm front extending east from a low in Minnesota.  The line produced a few spots of wind damage and one tornado.  A weak shower behind the line also managed to produce a funnel.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two large trees were downed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down near the west shore of Lake Leelanau, then moved out onto the lake and quickly dissipated. Docks and boats were damaged along a short stretch of shoreline, and a few trees were downed in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm produced wind damage in Big Rapids, where emergency management reported that 15 trees were snapped off or blown down.  Flooding also occurred in Big Rapids.  The Robin Hood airport in Big Rapids received 5.97 inches of rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported flooding about 3 miles west of the town of Chase, where a 3 foot deep road washout occurred at 56th and Queens highway in Yates township.
