EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid day with heat indices around 100 degrees ended with numerous severe thunderstorms across southeast Michigan as a cold front moved through the region.

A frontal boundary worked north into northern Indiana during the afternoon. A moderately unstable atmosphere was located south of the front with favorable freezing levels and shear. An upper level system moved through the area interacting with this boundary, providing the forcing for thunderstorm development. Some of these became severe with hail, wind damage and some reports of flooding.

Severe thunderstorms produced some damaging wind gusts across portions of Kent county where several tree limbs and power lines were blown down.  Several trees and power lines were also blown down across portions of Calhoun county and Clinton county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter near Bellevue estimated thunderstorm wind gusts up to 60 mph that brought down several branches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced some damaging wind gusts across portions of Kent county where several tree limbs and power lines were blown down.  Several trees and power lines were also blown down across portions of Calhoun county and Clinton county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Clinton county emergency manager reported that a couple of pine trees and branches and several power lines were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid day with heat indices around 100 degrees ended with numerous severe thunderstorms across southeast Michigan as a cold front moved through the region.
A hot and humid day with heat indices around 100 degrees ended with numerous severe thunderstorms across southeast Michigan as a cold front moved through the region.
Scattered showers and a few thunderstorms moved across Northern Lower Michigan.  One storm produced a tornado just before moving out over Tawas Bay.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several people witnessed the tornado touch down between US-23 and Tawas Bay.  The tornado was on the ground for less than a quarter-mile, crossing Douglas Drive just north of Lakeview Drive, before reaching the bay as a waterspout.  Forty trees were downed, and six homes suffered damage, mostly roof damage due to those falling trees.  Winds were estimated at 70 mph.

A batch of thunderstorms moving through during the evening hours produced scatter wind damage across southeast Michigan, along with flash flooding over Saginaw Bay and St. Clair counties where over 3 inches of rain fell in a short period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large tree limbs and a large tree were reported blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist unstable airmass was in place across southeast Michigan as a warm front had passed through the area the previous night. Storms developed out to the west along a cold front and moved through the area as an organized line of storms during the afternoon hours.  Numerous reports of tree damage were associated with the damaging wind gusts, with a few reports of large hail.  Heavy rain produced flooding in St. Clair County which continued during the overnight hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Central dispatch reported numerous roads closed and washed out. There was a substantial amount of flooding in Burtchville, Fort Gratiot, and the northeastern townships. Up to 100 homes received some form of flood damage, as the rain overwhelmed the drainage system.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid day with heat indices around 100 degrees ended with numerous severe thunderstorms across southeast Michigan as a cold front moved through the region.
A hot and humid day with heat indices around 100 degrees ended with numerous severe thunderstorms across southeast Michigan as a cold front moved through the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees reported blown down.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four inch diameter tree limbs reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid day with heat indices around 100 degrees ended with numerous severe thunderstorms across southeast Michigan as a cold front moved through the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees reported blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a house, which blew a hole in the roof and siding.

In the late afternoon and evening of September 3, 2011 several thunderstorms fired up ahead of a cold front that was draped across lower Michigan. Outflow boundaries from previous storms in the day provided the lift required to set these storms in motion. Many areas saw brief heavy downpours, but the areas hardest hit with strong winds and hail were along I-94 from Ann Arbor to downtown Detroit, and from Huntington Woods to Madison Heights. About 100,000 DTE customers lost power due to the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported blown down.

Outflow boundaries from previous storms in the day provided the lift required to set these storms in motion. About 100,000 DTE customers lost power due to the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain changed over to heavy wet snow during the afternoon and evening hours of November 29th as an intensifying low pressure system lifted north through Ohio. Snowfall amounts generally ranged between 6 and 9 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rain changed over to heavy wet snow Tuesday afternoon and continued into the evening hours before ending. There was a tight snowfall gradient across the county, with total snow accumulation ranging from around an inch or two in the far northwest to as much as 8 inches in far eastern portions of St. Joseph county. A trained spotter 3 miles south of Colon reported 7.5 inches of total snow accumulation, with snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour at times. The heavy wet snow created localized power outages, along with hazardous driving conditions which resulted in accidents and slide-offs. There were also reports of school delays and cancellations the next morning, mainly across far eastern St. Joseph County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain changed over to heavy wet snow during the afternoon and evening hours of November 29th as an intensifying low pressure system lifted north through Ohio. Snowfall amounts generally ranged between 6 and 9 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rain changed over to heavy wet snow Tuesday afternoon and continued into the evening hours before ending. Total snow accumulations ranged between 5 and 9 inches across the county. There was a public report of 8.0 inches of total snow accumulation at Sherwood with snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour at times. The heavy wet snow created localized power outages, along with hazardous driving conditions which resulted in accidents and slide-offs. There were also reports of school delays and cancellations the next morning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northwest winds caused rough waters along southeastern Lake Michigan.  Three teenagers were kayaking inside a New Buffalo break-wall when they capsized as a result of waves of at least 8 to 10 feet just offshore and over 14 feet onshore.  Two of the teens were recovered by local officials, but the third could not be rescued.  His body eventually came to shore about 12 miles southwest of where he went underwater.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong northwest winds caused rough waters along southeastern Lake Michigan. Three teenagers were kayaking inside a New Buffalo break wall when they capsized as a result of waves of at least 8 to 10 feet just offshore and over 14 feet onshore. Two of the teens were recovered by local officials, but the third, an 18 year old male, could not be rescued. His body eventually came to shore about 12 miles southwest of where he went underwater.  The condition of the other teens that were rescued was never provided.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening low pressure system lifting northeast of Upper Michigan into Ontario caused damaging winds across much of Upper Michigan near Lake Superior from the 14th into the early morning of the 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were reported down across the road near Pine Stump Junction.  Several three-foot diameter trees were reported down near the Pike Lake area along County Road 414.  Time was estimated from highest winds at Grand Marais GLOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain changed over to heavy wet snow during the afternoon and evening hours of November 29th as an intensifying low pressure system lifted north through Ohio. Snowfall amounts generally ranged between 6 and 9 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rain changed over to heavy wet snow Tuesday afternoon and continued into the evening hours before ending. Total snow accumulations ranged between 6 and 9 inches across the county. A trained spotter reported 8.5 inches of total snow accumulation 9 miles east of Jonesville, with snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour at times. The heavy wet snow created localized power outages, along with hazardous driving conditions which resulted in accidents and slide-offs. There were also reports of school delays and cancellations the next morning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant early season winter storm brought heavy wet snow and windy conditions to south central lower Michigan.  A swath of 8 to 10 inches of snow fell from Marshall northeast to Lansing and St. John's, with the highest total of 10 inches reported in St. John's.  There was a sharp gradient to the snow, with Battle Creek receiving around 5 inches of snow, and Kalamazoo and Hastings receiving only 3 inches.  In fact just a little further northwest in Grand Rapids there was no snow at all.  ||The combination of the heavy wet snow with high liquid content and strong winds and falling temperatures caused quite a few trees, tree limbs and power lines to come down near to east of a line from Battle Creek to Lansing and St. John's.  Approximately 30,000 people were left without power in south central Michigan.  There were numerous accidents.  A gas station awning in Haslett collapsed under the weight of the snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Battle Creek emergency management reported the combination of wind and heavy wet snow brought down numerous trees and power lines in and near Battle Creek.  A trained spotter reported 6.5 inches of snow in Albion.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening low pressure system lifting northeast of Upper Michigan into Ontario caused damaging winds across much of Upper Michigan near Lake Superior from the 14th into the early morning of the 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Measured wind gust at GLOS site in Grand Marais.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous large trees down on a private residence in Trowbridge Park during the night.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported numerous trees down on roads in Haslett where 9.5 inches of snow was reported.  WILX tv just south of downtown Lansing reported 9.7 inches of snow.  A Marathon gas station awning collapsed under the weight of the heavy wet snow in Haslett.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening low pressure system moving through the Upper Great Lakes caused heavy rain, damaging north winds and power outages from the evening of the 29th into the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong north winds from the storm knocked down numerous large trees across roads and power lines and caused widespread power outages across Marquette County from the evening of the 29th into the morning of the 30th.  Thousands of residences in Marquette, Harvey, Skandia, Negaunee, Ishpeming and Gwinn were without power from the evening of the 29th into the 30th.  Some customers were without power for several days.  The most extensive and widespread tree damage observed was on Partridge Bay Trail off of County Road 550 just northwest of Marquette where hundreds of one to two-foot diameter oak and quaking aspen trees were toppled across the road.  Heavy rain accompanying the storm also caused ponding of water on city streets.||In addition...bricks blown off the Pioneer Square Building in Ishpeming caused extensive damage to a pickup truck.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening low pressure system moving through the Upper Great Lakes caused heavy rain, damaging north winds and power outages from the evening of the 29th into the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were down and power knocked out in Ironwood and the west end of Lake Gogebic.  The top of a pine tree was also snapped off in Wakefield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening low pressure system moving through the Upper Great Lakes caused heavy rain, damaging north winds and power outages from the evening of the 29th into the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Keweenaw County Sheriff reported multiple large trees down across roads throughout Keweenaw County.  Power was out in Copper Harbor from 1545-2115 EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening low pressure system moving through the Upper Great Lakes caused heavy rain, damaging north winds and power outages from the evening of the 29th into the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Alger County Sheriff reported numerous trees down across roads and power lines across the county. Several of the trees were greater than 12 inches in diameter.

A swath of 8 to 10 inches of snow fell from Marshall northeast to Lansing and St. John's, with the highest total of 10 inches reported in St. John's.  There was a sharp gradient to the snow, with Battle Creek receiving around 5 inches of snow, and Kalamazoo and Hastings receiving only 3 inches.  In fact just a little further northwest in Grand Rapids there was no snow at all.  ||The combination of the heavy wet snow with high liquid content and strong winds and falling temperatures caused quite a few trees, tree limbs and power lines to come down near to east of a line from Battle Creek to Lansing and St. John's.  Approximately 30,000 people were left without power in south central Michigan.  There were numerous accidents.  A gas station awning in Haslett collapsed under the weight of the snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter in St. John's measured ten inches of snow.  The weight of the snow caused limbs and power lines to come down.  8.1 inches of snow was measured at Capital City Airport just northwest of downtown Lansing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure (985 MB) tracking through Detroit lead to strong northeast winds gusting to 60 mph in and around Saginaw Bay. Trees and large branches were brought down across the northern Thumb and Tri-Cities regions, leading to power outages. One tree branch landed on a woman and 3 year old, causing minor injuries.

In the late afternoon and evening of September 3, 2011 several thunderstorms fired up ahead of a cold front that was draped across lower Michigan. Outflow boundaries from previous storms in the day provided the lift required to set these storms in motion. Many areas saw brief heavy downpours, but the areas hardest hit with strong winds and hail were along I-94 from Ann Arbor to downtown Detroit, and from Huntington Woods to Madison Heights. About 100,000 DTE customers lost power due to the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and powerlines reported down in Ira Township, some of which fell onto houses.

The Grapevine Wildfire near Silver Lake Basin north of Ishpeming burned between 80 and 100 acres in late July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Grapevine Wildfire started on the afternoon of the 29th and burned into the 31st.  The wildfire burned between 80 and 100 acres.  Numerous local fire departments responded and help suppress the fire around its edges.  Heavy equipment was also used to build up barriers around the fire.  No structures were lost in the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid July heat wave helped cap off the warmest month on record at Detroit. Three direct deaths were reported due to the heat wave, as heat indices were above 100 degrees. Here are the high temperatures recorded for Detroit and Flint during the period of July  17th-22nd:||Flint, 95, 94, 94, 95, 99, 84.|Detroit, 92, 96, 94, 96, 100, 95.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported damage to a barn and a billboard being blwon down.

The approach of an upper disturbance from Minnesota heralded one of the most significant severe weather events of the season on the 30th.  Widespread damage was reported from Ontonagon and Baraga counties east through Marquette and Delta counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three-foot diameter tree downed in yard on County Road G18.  Time was estimated from radar.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported power lines and trees down onto the roadway, near Nottawwa and Ann Streets.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure was located over northwestern Iowa with a warm front well north into Michigan. The main upper level jet energy remained west of the area. The environment consisted of strong instability, with surface based CAPE in excess of 500 j/kg and low shear. Storms struggled initially with isolated reports of hail or wind damage. As the storms congealed, larger segments of storms took shape, causing more widespread wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported a large branch blown down onto power lines. Both the branch and power lines landed on a vehicle. No one was injured.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching warm front produced a few severe thunderstorms and heavy rain over portions of Houghton County on the morning of the 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pea to penny-sized hail was observed near Toivola.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Increasing afternoon instability on the 25th lead to the formation of a severe storm a few miles north of Rapid River.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Downed trees were also reported along a road due to the excessive downburst winds occurring at the same time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a dying thunderstorm complex moved over Lake Superior on the afternoon of the 30th, a seiche developed due to the wake low formed by the complex. No damage or injuries were reported from this event but water levels fluctuated by two to four feet in a matter of minutes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: As a dying thunderstorm complex moved over Lake Superior on the afternoon of the 30th, a seiche developed due to the wake low formed by the complex.  No damage or injuries were reported from this event but water levels fluctuated by two to four feet in a matter of minutes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported a 12 inch diameter tree blown down blocking portions of the 400 block of Ridgeway.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 37 year old highland man died from several factors including an enlarged heart, obesity and hyperthermia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm over Midland county spawned a brief tornado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A storm survey conducted by the National Weather Service confirms an EF0 tornado occurred in Midland County Sunday July 24, 2011. Video showed the tornado touched down on Sanford Lake just north of the mouth of Varity Creek and traveled 0.4 miles northeast before lifting near the south end of North Weeping Willow Lane. The tornado was 50 yards wide with wind speeds up to 65 MPH. Damage was limited to a boat hoist along with minor tree damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid July heat wave helped cap off the warmest month on record at Detroit. Three direct deaths were reported due to the heat wave, as heat indices were above 100 degrees. Here are the high temperatures recorded for Detroit and Flint during the period of July  17th-22nd:||Flint, 95, 94, 94, 95, 99, 84.|Detroit, 92, 96, 94, 96, 100, 95.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 60 year old man died due to hyperthermia, as he was found in his car with the windows rolled up. A 57 year old man was also found dead due to|hyperthermia in his Redford Township group home.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported trees and power lines down, mainly on the east side of Sturgis.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Bow echo complex moved from Illinois and Wisconsin into Southern Lower Michigan. In addition, a separate area of thunderstorms developed ahead of the main line. Strong instability and a continued feed of moisture fed the line as it raced east at speeds of up to 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local fire officials reported multiple trees and power lines down along Custer and Decker Roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High waves on southeastern Lake Michigan cause rough conditions along the lake shore areas, where rip currents were common. One rip current at New Buffalo Public beach contributed to the death of 25 year old, plus minor injuries to a lifeguard. A second man was also caught by the rip current, but was rescued from a swim buoy and refused treatment.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around 4:30 pm EDT, lifeguards on the New Buffalo public beach observed two men being pulled out by an apparent rip current. One of the men was able to grab onto a swim zone buoy. However his friend, a 25 year old man from Palos Hills, Illinois, was pulled out further into the lake. A lifeguard was able to rescue the man on the buoy, but waves as high as 12 feet prevented rescuers from reaching the other person. Eventually, a special Coast Guard boat able to handle the high waves, was called in and eventually found the 25 year old male's body floating along the shore. The other swimmer that was rescued refused medical treatment.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed over North Central and Northeast Lower Michigan, thanks to a humid and unstable airmass.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A family was on a tubing outing on the Au Sable River.  A thunderstorm rapidly developed, and they attempted to exit the river and find shelter.  They were just out of the river, when three individuals were struck by lightning.  Two women were pronounced dead at the scene.  A man was transported to a hospital in Saginaw in critical condition.  He would survive, but require a 10-day hospital stay, and considerable physical therapy after that.  The survivor had no recollection of the incident.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered rain showers developed over Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 23rd.  These did not get especially strong, but one managed to produce a waterspout.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The waterspout formed from an otherwise unimpressive rain shower on the Helmer Bay portion of Manistique Lake in Luce County. It drifted south, crossing into Mackinac County, and soon dissipated over the southeastern portion of the lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Three to six foot waves caused some rip currents to develop along the shores of southeastern Lake Michigan. A 44 year old man was swimming at a beach near Coloma, Michigan where he drowned after being pulled out by the rip current.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media reported a 44 year old male from Wheeling, Illinois was having trouble swimming at the beach off of Hagar Township Park. A woman with the swimmer lost sight of him and began yelling for help. Four minutes later rescuers arrived. He was in the water for approximately 90 minutes before a Coast Guard helicopter crew was able to recover his body.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few severe thunderstorms hit the northern suburbs of Detroit, as well as Ann Arbor.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter estimated 60 mph thunderstorm wind gust which brought down power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms moved across Northern Lower Michigan, producing damaging winds in a few spots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two trees and numerous power lines were downed.  A garage was damaged by a fallen tree.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms moved across Northern Lower Michigan, producing damaging winds in a few spots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A couple of trees were downed.  A pickup truck suffered minor damage from a fallen tree.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms moved across Northern Lower Michigan, producing damaging winds in a few spots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Scattered tree damage, including a few downed trees, occurred in the Atlanta area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Intense thunderstorm rain lead to rainfall totals of 3 to 7 inches, generally in a 12 hour period of less, which lead to flash flooding across a few counties in southeast Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lots of roads in and around central Oakland county reported flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the late afternoon and evening of September 3, 2011 several thunderstorms fired up ahead of a cold front that was draped across lower Michigan. Outflow boundaries from previous storms in the day provided the lift required to set these storms in motion. Many areas saw brief heavy downpours, but the areas hardest hit with strong winds and hail were along I-94 from Ann Arbor to downtown Detroit, and from Huntington Woods to Madison Heights. About 100,000 DTE customers lost power due to the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and large limbs reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm impacted Shelby Township in Macomb County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large tree limbs blown down along Shelby Road between 23 and 24 Mile roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm spawned a brief weak tornado over Monroe County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado was reported to have struck the Village Meadows Subdivision, causing minor damage to a garage roof and knocking over a wooden play structure.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of heavy rain and thunderstorms moved across southwest lower Michigan from July 27 to July 29, flooding roadways and intersections across areas near to mainly south of Interstate 96.  The most significant impacts from flash flooding occurred in and near the Lansing area.  Radar estimated that 6 to 10 inches of rain fell from July 27 to 29 near and southwest of Lansing.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Barry county road commission indicated that there were numerous road closures and washouts.  Radar indicates that six to eight inches of rain fell across northeast and east Barry county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of heavy rain and thunderstorms moved across southwest lower Michigan from July 27 to July 29, flooding roadways and intersections across areas near to mainly south of Interstate 96.  The most significant impacts from flash flooding occurred in and near the Lansing area.  Radar estimated that 6 to 10 inches of rain fell from July 27 to 29 near and southwest of Lansing.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to eight inches of rain fell across far northern Jackson county from the late evening hours of July 27 through the early morning hours of July 29.  This caused flash flooding and several road closures and washouts across that area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of heavy rain and thunderstorms moved across southwest lower Michigan from July 27 to July 29, flooding roadways and intersections across areas near to mainly south of Interstate 96.  The most significant impacts from flash flooding occurred in and near the Lansing area.  Radar estimated that 6 to 10 inches of rain fell from July 27 to 29 near and southwest of Lansing.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dispatch reported numerous incidents of cars stuck in water and rapidly flowing water flooding streets. Sections of Diamond and Turner Avenue were impassible.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of heavy rain and thunderstorms moved across southwest lower Michigan from July 27 to July 29, flooding roadways and intersections across areas near to mainly south of Interstate 96.  The most significant impacts from flash flooding occurred in and near the Lansing area.  Radar estimated that 6 to 10 inches of rain fell from July 27 to 29 near and southwest of Lansing.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Road washouts occurred as 2 to 4 inches of rain fell on Gratiot County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A marginal severe thunderstorm produced a brief tornado in Lakefield Township in Saginaw County.  Then another isolated severe thunderstorm moved through the northern suburbs of Detroit.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A weak tornado over Lafayette Township in Gratiot County tracked east-northeast into Saginaw County before lifting. Just some minor crop damage was observed, with winds estimated at 70 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of severe thunderstorms struck from Muskegon to Newaygo and Isabella counties on the morning of September 3rd. A National Weather Service storm survey found a 40 mile path of intermittent downburst wind damage, with winds estimated to be from 40 to 70 mph.||Several trees were downed at around 8:35 a.m. in the southern part of the town of Newaygo. Scattered tree damage continued to Croton Dam. After a brief break, damage resumed near Morley in southern Mecosta County and continued to Remus in eastern Mecosta County where scattered trees and large limbs were downed. The most concentrated area of damage occurred in western Isabella County just northeast of Millbrook, where peak winds were estimated at 70 mph around 9:55 a.m. A tree fell on a house and roofs were damaged on an outbuilding and a trailer home.||Strong to severe thunderstorms struck Calhoun and Jackson Counties in the early evening. One inch diameter hail fell near Leroy in Calhoun County and several trees were downed along the path of the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement in Grand Haven reported that two trees were blown down.

Scattered tree damage continued to Croton Dam. After a brief break, damage resumed near Morley in southern Mecosta County and continued to Remus in eastern Mecosta County where scattered trees and large limbs were downed. The most concentrated area of damage occurred in western Isabella County just northeast of Millbrook, where peak winds were estimated at 70 mph around 9:55 a.m. A tree fell on a house and roofs were damaged on an outbuilding and a trailer home.||Strong to severe thunderstorms struck Calhoun and Jackson Counties in the early evening. One inch diameter hail fell near Leroy in Calhoun County and several trees were downed along the path of the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement from Muskegon reported receiving reports of numerous trees and power lines down across the county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An NWS storm survey revealed that several trees were downed in the town of Newaygo and that scattered tree damage continued to Croton Dam.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of heavy rain and thunderstorms moved across southwest lower Michigan from July 27 to July 29, flooding roadways and intersections across areas near to mainly south of Interstate 96.  The most significant impacts from flash flooding occurred in and near the Lansing area.  Radar estimated that 6 to 10 inches of rain fell from July 27 to 29 near and southwest of Lansing.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to eight inches of rain fell across roughly the southwestern half of Ingham county from the late evening hours of July 27 through the early morning hours of July 29.  This caused flash flooding and numerous road closures and washouts.||Water reached as high as street side mailboxes and to several homes on slabs in the Burchfield Drive neighborhood in Lansing, MI, where boat rescues were necessary. Many homes had 3 to 4 feet of water in their basements. At least five homes were destroyed in Lansing with several others uninhabitable according to the local fire department. Twenty additional homes suffered significant damage from water in Lansing and across Ingham County. One apartment building in Lansing was evacuated when sewage backed up into the building with the inflow of rain water. Nine people were rescued by boat. The Red Cross opened a shelter at a local high school in Lansing for evacuees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of heavy rain and thunderstorms moved across southwest lower Michigan from July 27 to July 29, flooding roadways and intersections across areas near to mainly south of Interstate 96.  The most significant impacts from flash flooding occurred in and near the Lansing area.  Radar estimated that 6 to 10 inches of rain fell from July 27 to 29 near and southwest of Lansing.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to eight inches of rain fell across much of Eaton county from the late evening hours of July 27 through the early morning hours of July 29.  This caused flash flooding and numerous road closures and washouts.  A co-op observer measured 7.15 inches of rain in Diamondale.  Three to four feet of ponding water in a field in Diamondale damaged several pieces of farm equipment that were part of a farm implement show.||Interstate 69 was closed in Eaton County between Vermontville Highway and Windsor Road due to rapidly flowing water over the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracking eastward through the Lower Great Lakes brought significant heavy wet snow to south central Upper Michigan.  With a strong high pressure system centered over Ontario providing very dry air across Lake Superior and northern Upper Michigan, there was a very sharp snowfall gradient between the heavy snow and no snow at all.  The pressure difference across the area also resulted in gusty east winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall of 13 inches in about 12 hours was recorded in Wallace, MI.  Other snowfall reports included 10 inches in Menominee and 8 inches in Carney.  Winds gusting over 40 mph especially along the lake shore resulted in significant blowing and drifting snow and the closure of some roads along the lake in Menominee.  School and government buildings were also closed for the day.  The snowfall gradient was very sharp with areas north of US 2 seeing very little snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A marginal severe thunderstorm produced a brief tornado in Lakefield Township in Saginaw County.  Then another isolated severe thunderstorm moved through the northern suburbs of Detroit.
A marginal severe thunderstorm produced a brief tornado in Lakefield Township in Saginaw County.  Then another isolated severe thunderstorm moved through the northern suburbs of Detroit.

A marginal severe thunderstorm produced a brief tornado in Lakefield Township in Saginaw County.  Then another isolated severe thunderstorm moved through the northern suburbs of Detroit.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Small tree branches up to 3 inches in diameter were reported blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon and early evening hours across southern lower Michigan and produced reports of several scattered downed trees and power lines across portions of Kent and Ionia counties.  This occurred due to gusty severe thunderstorm wind gusts of up to 60 mph.  The Gerald Ford Airport in Grand Rapids had a measured peak wind gust to 52 mph and a trained spotter measured a peak wind gust to 55 mph four miles north northwest of Lowell.  Hail up to three quarters inch in diameter was reported near Scottville.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong thunderstorm produced predominantly one half inch hail with several three quarters inch diameter hailstones five miles south of Scottville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the late afternoon and evening of September 3, 2011 several thunderstorms fired up ahead of a cold front that was draped across lower Michigan. Outflow boundaries from previous storms in the day provided the lift required to set these storms in motion. Many areas saw brief heavy downpours, but the areas hardest hit with strong winds and hail were along I-94 from Ann Arbor to downtown Detroit, and from Huntington Woods to Madison Heights. About 100,000 DTE customers lost power due to the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and powerlines reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A marginal severe thunderstorm produced a brief tornado in Lakefield Township in Saginaw County.  Then another isolated severe thunderstorm moved through the northern suburbs of Detroit.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A person from the general public estimated a 60 mph thunderstorm wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms were concentrated mostly along the M-59 corridor, causing the Dream Cruise along Woodward Avenue to be cut short, as minor damage was reported. The other notable item from this event was a weak tornado reported near Chesaning in Saginaw County.

An isolated severe thunderstorm produced wind damage in Big Rapids, where emergency management reported that 15 trees were snapped off or blown down.  Flooding also occurred in Big Rapids.  The Robin Hood airport in Big Rapids received 5.97 inches of rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cars floated in flood waters on State street in Big Rapids as reported by emergency management.  County emergency management also reported that numerous other roads in and near Big Rapids experienced some flooding. ||One of the washed out roads stranded over 800 Boy Scouts at a local camp in Mecosta County.  Ferris State University in Big Rapids, Michigan reported 25 buildings on campus with water damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind damage included downed trees and power lines across portions of Calhoun, Kent and Ottawa counties.  The southern half of Newaygo county experienced significant flooding where campers in Henning Park just east northeast of the town of Newaygo were evacuated.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant flooding occurred across the southern half of Newaygo county and campers in Henning Park just east northeast of Newaygo had to be evacuated. These campers were part of the Newaygo National Kayak and Canoeing Championships.  Several roads in the county were closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms developed over southeast Michigan, with both large hail and wind damage occurring.

A line of severe thunderstorms struck from Muskegon to Newaygo and Isabella counties on the morning of September 3rd. A National Weather Service storm survey found a 40 mile path of intermittent downburst wind damage, with winds estimated to be from 40 to 70 mph.||Several trees were downed at around 8:35 a.m. in the southern part of the town of Newaygo. Scattered tree damage continued to Croton Dam. After a brief break, damage resumed near Morley in southern Mecosta County and continued to Remus in eastern Mecosta County where scattered trees and large limbs were downed. The most concentrated area of damage occurred in western Isabella County just northeast of Millbrook, where peak winds were estimated at 70 mph around 9:55 a.m. A tree fell on a house and roofs were damaged on an outbuilding and a trailer home.||Strong to severe thunderstorms struck Calhoun and Jackson Counties in the early evening. One inch diameter hail fell near Leroy in Calhoun County and several trees were downed along the path of the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An NWS storm survey found that scattered trees and large limbs were blown down from Morley to Remus.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A storm survey conducted by the National Weather Service confirmed an EF0 tornado near Chesaning on Saturday August 20, 2011. The track began near the intersection of Mckeighan and Baldwin roads at approximately 300 pm. The tornado then tracked east and ended near the intersection of Chesaning and Stuart roads. The tornado was 100 yards wide with wind speeds up to 80 mph. Damage was mainly limited to large trees and an overturned trailer.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gust measured by the Grand Marais GLOS station.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist unstable airmass was in place across southeast Michigan as a warm front had passed through the area the previous night. Storms developed out to the west along a cold front and moved through the area as an organized line of storms during the afternoon hours.  Numerous reports of tree damage were associated with the damaging wind gusts, with a few reports of large hail.  Heavy rain produced flooding in St. Clair County which continued during the overnight hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 30 year old woman was struck by lighting as she tried to enter her automobile. She become unconscious and was not breathing. CPR was performed. She was transported to the hospital and did survive.

Numerous reports of tree damage were associated with the damaging wind gusts, with a few reports of large hail.  Heavy rain produced flooding in St. Clair County which continued during the overnight hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms forming along a slow moving low pressure system and associated warm front dropped heavy rainfall of four to five inches over portions of Delta County from the 21st into the 22nd.  Many other counties over central Upper Michigan measured two to three inches during the same event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Stonington measured 5.38 inches of rainfall in 24 hours.  The observer southeast of Bark River measured 4.24 inches over the same period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two separate bow echoes moved across western lower Michigan during the morning hours of July 11, producing numerous reports of wind damage.  The first bow echo moved onshore north of Muskegon shortly after daybreak.  The second bow echo proved to be more destructive as it raced east from northern Illinois across far southern Lake Michigan and southern lower Michigan, resulting in numerous reports of downed trees and power lines.  One person lost his life in Cutlerville when a tree fell in the garage he was in.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A bow echo raced east across Allegan county during the late morning hours, bringing down numerous trees and power lines in areas including the city of Allegan and several miles south of Holland.  Radar data suggests that downed trees were likely countywide.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A bow echo raced east across Kalamazoo county during the late morning hours, bringing down numerous trees and power lines. A trained spotter reported a measured wind gust of 71 mph in Schoolcraft.  The public report lots of tree damage in and near Portage.  Radar data suggests that downed trees were likely countywide.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two separate bow echoes moved across western lower Michigan during the morning hours of July 11, producing numerous reports of wind damage.  The first bow echo moved onshore north of Muskegon shortly after daybreak.  The second bow echo proved to be more destructive as it raced east from northern Illinois across far southern Lake Michigan and southern lower Michigan, resulting in numerous reports of downed trees and power lines.  One person lost his life in Cutlerville when a tree fell in the garage he was in.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Radar data indicates the northern end of a strong bow echo moved east into southwestern Kent county at 10:45 a.m. and raced east northeast producing significant wind damage and exited far east central Kent county near Lowell at around 11:10 a.m.  Numerous trees and power lines were blown down and uprooted in and near towns including Cutlerville, Wyoming and Kentwood.||A 38 year old man was killed inside his garage along 68th street SE in Cutlerville when wind gusts of up to 80 mph ripped a large tree and its roots out of the ground and toppling it onto the garage, splitting it in half.  In addition, a woman suffered minor injuries when a tree fell on her home in Cutlerville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two separate bow echoes moved across western lower Michigan during the morning hours of July 11, producing numerous reports of wind damage.  The first bow echo moved onshore north of Muskegon shortly after daybreak.  The second bow echo proved to be more destructive as it raced east from northern Illinois across far southern Lake Michigan and southern lower Michigan, resulting in numerous reports of downed trees and power lines.  One person lost his life in Cutlerville when a tree fell in the garage he was in.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Van Buren county sheriff's department reported numerous areas of tree damage countywide in addition to widespread power outages across the southern half of the county.  Some of the harder hit areas included Mattawan, Lawton and Hartford.  In fact 20 to 25 pine trees were blown down on one property just northeast of Lawton.  A trained spotter reported a roof was blown off a ballfield dugout and cinder blocks were blown 30 feet, also in Lawton.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees were blown down across portions of Van Buren county, primarily in the vicinity of Paw Paw.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another day of thunderstorms in Northern Michigan, though considerably more widespread and stronger than the day before.  A cold front moved into the hot and humid airmass still in place across the region, triggering numerous severe thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines were downed in Lake Leelanau.  The Inland Seas Academy in Suttons Bay measured a 60 mph gust, while a nearby ship measured 56 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The approach of an upper disturbance from Minnesota heralded one of the most significant severe weather events of the season on the 30th.  Widespread damage was reported from Ontonagon and Baraga counties east through Marquette and Delta counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees reported down.  Time was estimated from the radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the mid to late afternoon hours of May 29 from Vicksburg east northeast to Battle Creek and Charlotte.  An NWS storm survey found significant damage resulting from straight line wind damage resulting from severe thunderstorm winds of up to 85 to 100 mph.  A state of emergency was declared for Calhoun county due to widespread wind damage.||The storms developed north of a warm front that separated mild weather to the north of it from hot weather south of the boundary.  The storms traveled into northern Illinois just after noon, and then moved across southern lower Michigan between 2 pm and 6 pm. The storms strengthened as they reached far southern lower Michigan as they encountered warmer and more humid air.  The NWS Grand Rapids storm survey teams found no conclusive evidence of any tornadoes from southern Kalamazoo county east northeast through Calhoun county and up into Eaton and Ingham counties.  Nearly 40,000 people across Calhoun county lost power due to all the wind damage and lightning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The bowing segment caused damage in a stretch nearly 7 miles long and 0.5 mile in width from approximately the Ingham county border east into the city of Mason. This path was a continuation of the damage in Eaton county. Strong winds uprooted or snapped numerous large trees in addition to downing power lines near the Mason area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the mid to late afternoon hours of May 29 from Vicksburg east northeast to Battle Creek and Charlotte.  An NWS storm survey found significant damage resulting from straight line wind damage resulting from severe thunderstorm winds of up to 85 to 100 mph.  A state of emergency was declared for Calhoun county due to widespread wind damage.||The storms developed north of a warm front that separated mild weather to the north of it from hot weather south of the boundary.  The storms traveled into northern Illinois just after noon, and then moved across southern lower Michigan between 2 pm and 6 pm. The storms strengthened as they reached far southern lower Michigan as they encountered warmer and more humid air.  The NWS Grand Rapids storm survey teams found no conclusive evidence of any tornadoes from southern Kalamazoo county east northeast through Calhoun county and up into Eaton and Ingham counties.  Nearly 40,000 people across Calhoun county lost power due to all the wind damage and lightning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A nearly 3 mile damage path 0.5-1 mile in width was reported in southeastern Ingham county between Swan Road and Dansville road east of US 52. The damage was was caused by a bowing segment that passed through this area. Several barns were damaged, and a garagee was blown down. The garage was not properly secured to the foundation, however. Additionally, some power lines in the area were down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level disturbance contributed to a second round of strong to severe thunderstorms across Northern Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail covered the ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the late afternoon and evening of September 3, 2011 several thunderstorms fired up ahead of a cold front that was draped across lower Michigan. Outflow boundaries from previous storms in the day provided the lift required to set these storms in motion. Many areas saw brief heavy downpours, but the areas hardest hit with strong winds and hail were along I-94 from Ann Arbor to downtown Detroit, and from Huntington Woods to Madison Heights. About 100,000 DTE customers lost power due to the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Powerlines reported blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid day with heat indices around 100 degrees ended with numerous severe thunderstorms across southeast Michigan as a cold front moved through the region.

Another day of thunderstorms in Northern Michigan, though considerably more widespread and stronger than the day before.  A cold front moved into the hot and humid airmass still in place across the region, triggering numerous severe thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small branch was also downed by wind.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another day of thunderstorms in Northern Michigan, though considerably more widespread and stronger than the day before.  A cold front moved into the hot and humid airmass still in place across the region, triggering numerous severe thunderstorms.
A cold front moving through a warm and unstable airmass triggered a line of severe thunderstorms which affected portions of the Keweenaw Peninsula on the evening of the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Approximately 2-foot diameter pine tree was uprooted in the backyard of a house on Rockland Street.  The tree was lying in a north-northeast direction.  Time of the report was estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few severe thunderstorms, including one tornadic cell, tracked across Midland and Bay counties and into Saginaw Bay, and finally impacting far northern Huron County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado was rated EF1 with maximum winds to 95 mph. The path width was 200 yards with a path length of 8.4 miles. The tornado started near Parish road and 11 mile road just west of the community of Beaver. The tornado then moved through Beaver, crossed Interstate 75, and finally across the south part of Linwood before moving out to Saginaw Bay at 737 pm. A barn was destroyed and homes were damaged near Beaver, mostly to garages and roofing material. Numerous trees were uprooted with snapped large limbs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous severe thunderstorms impacted areas south of M-59.

Severe thunderstorms were concentrated mostly along the M-59 corridor, causing the Dream Cruise along Woodward Avenue to be cut short, as minor damage was reported. The other notable item from this event was a weak tornado reported near Chesaning in Saginaw County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dozens of large branches and trees reported down. Scattered roof damage and minor structural damage to Greenhouses.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms developed over southeast Michigan, with both large hail and wind damage occurring.
A cold front moving through around Midnight produced numerous severe thunderstorms across southeast Michigan, with a measured wind gust of 76 mph recorded in Flint.

Scattered severe thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon hours of the 12th across portions of Allegan and Barry counties, resulting in hail reports of up to one inch in diameter.  The thunderstorms were very slow movers and also produced reports of significant rainfall with minor flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail up to an inch in diameter was reported three miles south southwest of Middleville near Bowens Mills.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An MCS moved into the southern portions of the county warning area during the evening hours. As the system move east northeast through southern lower Michigan, scattered wind damage was reported in Van Buren, Kalamazoo, Calhoun, and Ingham counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported isolated tree damage and power lines down in the Gobles area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep low pressure system moving through northwest Ontario pushed a warm front across western Upper Michigan in the morning hours...followed by a cold frontal passage in the afternoon.  The frontal boundaries produced several severe thunderstorms and two weak tornadoes over western Upper Michigan on the 19th.

Bow echo complex moved from Illinois and Wisconsin into Southern Lower Michigan. In addition, a separate area of thunderstorms developed ahead of the main line. Strong instability and a continued feed of moisture fed the line as it raced east at speeds of up to 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported two trees down, as well as roof damage to a commercial building. Damage is estimated at $15,000.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching warm front produced a few severe thunderstorms and heavy rain over portions of Houghton County on the morning of the 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This was a public report from Toivola of 4.5 inches of rain in six hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm complex rolled through southeast Michigan during the peak heating of the day, resulting in scattered wind damage reports across the area. Embedded circulations within the line of thunderstorms lead to localized wind gusts to 80 mph, with even one confirmed tornado over southern Shiawassee county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was reported blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms triggered by a warm front moving across the area dumped heavy rain over portions of Houghton County during the early morning of the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter southeast of Chassel measured 2.45 inches of rain in a two and a half hour period with greater than one-inch per hour rainfall rates.  Several inches of water covered Highway 41 near Chassel and Calumet during the heavy rain event.  Water was also reported over several secondary roads near and just north of Chassel.  In addition to the heavy rain, a lightning strike in northern Wisconsin around 3:30 AM CDT knocked out the main electrical transmission lines to the western half of Upper Michigan.  Power was knocked out to nearly 75,000 residents for many hours throughout the western half of Upper Michigan.  The power outage resulted in numerous school and business closures.  For more information on the actual location of the lightning strike refer to the Storm Data entries for northern Wisconsin.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On a hot and humid day in Northern Michigan, clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms developed in Eastern Upper and Northeast Lower Michigan.  A number of wind gusts in the 50 to 55 mph range were also reported in Alpena County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail covered the ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced some damaging wind gusts across portions of Kent county where several tree limbs and power lines were blown down.  Several trees and power lines were also blown down across portions of Calhoun county and Clinton county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Estimated thunderstorm wind gusts to 60 mph brought down several tree limbs that were two feet in diameter in Riverside Park between Coit Avenue and Knapp Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few severe storms impacted areas south of M-59.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions gave way to a batch of thunderstorms, with numerous severe reports across southeast Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dozens of trees and power lines were reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid day with heat indices around 100 degrees ended with numerous severe thunderstorms across southeast Michigan as a cold front moved through the region.

The approach of an upper disturbance from Minnesota heralded one of the most significant severe weather events of the season on the 30th.  Widespread damage was reported from Ontonagon and Baraga counties east through Marquette and Delta counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gust measured by the Sawyer Airport AWOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving through a warm unstable airmass produced numerous thunderstorms over central Upper Michigan on the evening of the 17th.  A few storms turned severe over Menominee County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down on power lines along Anderson Road in Daggett County between 9 and 930 pm CDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms which weakened across Lake Michigan produced an outflow boundary. This boundary worked into far southern Lower Michigan and interacted with a lake breeze boundary to promote rapid storm development. Reports of damaging winds and some hail were received, but the storms failed to maintain their severity eastward as a large outflow boundary work across and south of the area, cutting off the limited available moisture.
A cold front was located to the west of the area. Unstable conditions and weak convergence allowed for isolated thunderstorm development.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement officials reported a large tree down in the Jefferson Township area.
